subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Troeth) proposed:
That the report from the committee be adopted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add "and that the Senate:
(a) notes the Government's intention to spend $1.2 million on a public education and awareness campaign about country of origin representations; and

(b) calls on the Government to ensure that this campaign honestly informs consumers that items labelled as `made in Australia' can legally contain imported ingredients or components, provided their value does not exceed 50% of the cost of production, without the need to disclose this fact".

If the government is going to spend over $1 million of taxpayers' money on an education campaign, presumably aimed at Australian consumers, I am totally opposed to that money going into a campaign that adds up to the mass deception of Australians, not least the people who go shopping in supermarkets and reach for made in Australia goods by preference. I think that is most Australians. What this piece of legislation does, because the Green amendments failed, is allow a mass deception of consumers in Australia. It pulls the rug from under those dinkum Australian producers whose products are 100 per cent or virtually 100 per cent made in Australia of Australian ingredients.

This legislation that the government, supported by the Labor Party, has put through enables producers who have spent 50 per cent of the cost of production here in this country to get away with labelling their products `Made in Australia' with no further explanation, although 49 per cent of the cost has been accrued overseas. As costs are very often lower overseas than in this country, it means, for example, that the majority of ingredients in the product on the supermarket shelf can be from overseas but that the item still has `Made in Australia' on it.

I will give an example of a jar of strawberry jam. One jar of jam can contain strawberries wholly produced in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania or Western Australia while the jar next to it can contain strawberries wholly produced in South America or South Africa. But both can have `Made in Australia' on the labels. Consumers do not know which is the Australian ingredient product or which is the imported ingredient product. There will be no ability for consumers in these circumstances to go for the Aussie made goods.

I find it quite incredible that we are facing now, within the next few minutes, a vote which is going to make this deception of consumers legal. You have to have a good imagination to work out some justification for this. You know what you end up with? You end up with exporters, principally multinational corporations, thinking that the made in Australia label enhances their business. People overseas value the made in Australia label, so if they can stick that on their produce, and not have to explain that the ingredients come from somewhere else, they will get a competitive edge overseas. The downside of this is that inside this country there are many producers—in particular the small businesses that Senator Troeth talked about a while ago—whose competitive edge is that the ingredients in their products as well as the work that is put into them are from this country. They should be able to put made in Australia pure and simple on their goods and gain that competitive edge. But they cannot under this legislation; they lose that competitive edge. The factory next door, which has components made overseas, can put exactly the same label on. As I said, the consumers cannot tell the difference.

What the multinationals gain in deceptive advertising legalised through this format in their exports, the dinkum Australian producers lose. It is not only the dinkum Australian producers—and I am talking about thousands of small businesses across this country, in particular primary producers in regional Australia—who lose the advantage of having their product here in Australia, it is also the 18 million consumers in Australia. This is legalised deception of the consumers. If you cannot have truth in advertising coming from government, where on earth will you get it from? This is not truth in advertising; this is institutionalised fraud. It is nothing more or less.

The best defence that Senator Troeth will have when she gets up is to say that there is a label that says `Product of Australia' and that will be the 100 per cent Australian made goods. I will respond to that in anticipation, because I will not get another say here. The Australian Consumers Association has cited a number of studies done by private enterprise in this country which show that consumers do not differentiate between the labels `Product of Australia' and `Made in Australia'. Why should they? If you look at the dictionary, they mean the same thing.

I suppose what this $1 million will be spent on is a futile effort to get consumers, with their lifetime habits, discerning between `Made in Australia' and `Product of Australia'. It is a con and a waste of money. I believe this amendment should be adopted because it at least says that if are you going to spend that money you should be honest about it and inform the consumers of Australia—the Australian people—that when they see `Made in Australia' on their labels in the future it can mean that up to 50 per cent is not made in Australia. It is a simple act of honesty with the people of this country.

I reiterate that this legislation did not begin in this place. It began in the House of Representatives. It had a swift passage through there with no opposition. Most remarkable of all, the member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson, the leader of the One Nation Party, who ascribes to being the real Australian defender, failed to get to her feet. She failed to take any part in this debate. She, by her silence, con sented to this sell-out of Australian buyers, small businesses and primary producers.

No less remarkable is the stand of the National Farmers Federation and the representative of the pork producers whose silence is deafening and, worse than that, whose consent has gone into this legislation. How dare they consent to legislation which is against the interests of primary producers in this country. It is against the interests of primary producers because, when it comes to buyers—and 80 per cent of them are in the cities in supermarkets buying foodstuffs, for example, but this applies to all other goods—their produce is going to be indistinguishable from produce coming from elsewhere around the world where costs, particularly labour costs, are lower and where there is very often government assistance for exports—and that means for imports into Australia.

We have seen all the concern about dumping in this country where our own producers are up against it. What is the government doing about that? It is pulling the rug from under our own producers—and the National Farmers Federation gives it a tick and says, `We'll support this one.' I cannot find rhyme or reason in this; it defies logic. Above all, it defies the dictum that there should be truth in advertising. When governments start to deceive their own people, you certainly lose faith in government and you lose faith in representation.

I am very frustrated that this matter has not been properly aired in the public arena. I feel very frustrated that there has not been a proper public debate about this. I know from mixing with Australians and, in particular, Tasmanians in recent times that people are appalled when they hear about this. They cannot believe that not only the government but the Labor Party should be supporting this form of legislation. For the Labor Party to say, `If it doesn't work, we'll fix it later,' is not good enough. The time to stop this is now. We ought to be stopping it in its tracks right now. It is a shameful piece of legislation.

Putting on a label `Made in Australia' that falsely implies that it is wholly made in Australia to people buying our goods overseas is bad enough, but to be doing it to the Australian public is reprehensible. I am not alone in this because it seems that when most people I know go to the supermarket, go to a liquor sales outlet or go to a clothing shop they will, like me, look for the `Australian-made' label. It might not be sensible shopping—I might end up paying a slightly higher price—but I don't care. It is about creating jobs in this country and it is about supporting businesses that put their profits back into this country. It is about standing by this country of Australia.

It stonkers me to think that in future the ability to do that is going to be defrauded by this piece of legislation. This is one of the most amazing pieces of legislation I have seen in my time in any parliament—in Tasmania or in this place. I think the government should hang its head in shame.

talk.start.para: —I will need to ask Senator Brown a question about the wording of his amendment to the report for the Trade Practices Amendment (Country of Origin Representations) Bill 1998 but I will make a quick couple of comments. Earlier in this debate, I did point out that the government's campaign will need to be very good. I do certainly agree with Senator Brown—although I am not sure I agree with all that he said—that there will be a confusion between `Product of Australia' and `Made in Australia'. The campaign will need to be very clear at that point, otherwise it is not going to be very helpful to the Australian consumer that we have debated this legislation and passed it in this place.

speech.para: The Democrats support this legislation as being better than nothing. It is an advance. We have done a lot of work on this issue. We have, in fact, on a number of occasions proposed our own legislation in this place and we have conducted tests in chain stores in Adelaide which show that people do want to buy Australian products if they can understand how they can do that. It is very clear that legislation is certainly needed.

We would have preferred the scheme that we came up with or some variation of that, but we are stuck with `Product of Australia' and `Made in Australia'. I am aware that the Labor Party, as well as the government, seems to be stuck on this way of identifying products. I believe it is confusing. It really will be up to the government to make it very clear in its advertising campaign, otherwise the confusion will continue.
I come to my question to Senator Brown. Senator, the last few words seem superfluous to me. In (b) you say:

calls on the Government to ensure that this campaign honestly informs consumers that items labelled as "made in Australia" can legally contain imported ingredients or components, provided their value does not exceed 50% of the cost of production, . . .

I would have put a full stop in there rather than a comma, because I am not sure what you mean when you then say `without the need to disclose this fact'. That does not seem to add anything in terms of meaning.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The phrase `without the need to disclose this fact' means that when there are imported ingredients in a product it ought to have `Made in Australia' with a subheading `of imported ingredients'. It is not going to under this legislation; it can simply have `Made in Australia'. We believe that an education campaign should tell people that there can be imported ingredients in a product and that it will not be stated on the label. The need to disclose imported ingredients in a made in Australia product will not have to be disclosed under this legislation.

—A statement has been made already by the government that they will be expending $1.2 million to try to inform consumers of the difference between `Made in Australia' and `Product of Australia'. I am not certain that what may seem on the face of it a large amount of money in buying advertising is really going to be sufficient to explain that. That being the case, I cannot see that it is at all inconsistent with the amendment that is put forward by Senator Brown.

speech.para: There is one other matter I would like to comment on while I am on my feet, and it relates to a comment made by Senator Woodley that the opposition seems wedded to the particular terminology that is contained in this bill. That is not the case. It is not a view I have expressed anywhere in the debate. If you understood that to be the opposition position, maybe I have not made it clear. Our position is much like yours. We see a lot of concern in the community about the failure by this government to take action since the 1996 election, and we see it preferable to have something in place. We felt that the only way to ensure that something would be in place before the coming election was to allow it passage. But we are concerned about the way it operates and the terminology and the fact that it may not be possible to explain to consumers properly the difference between those two terms. As I have said during the debate, we will be monitoring it, and if it is necessary to make changes to the terminology or to the definitions of those terms we will be making those changes in the future.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I would like to say to Senator Brown that the government will be supporting his amendment, but there are some comments I would like to make in relation to that. Many of Senator Brown's friends may know what to look for when they go into a supermarket, a liquor shop or a clothing shop, but it is an undeniable fact that many consumers do not know what to look for. This legislation will provide them with guidance on that with a much better definition of what `Made in Australia' and `Product of Australia' are all about. This legislation is not a con. It will be informing the consumer in a way that has not happened before. There has been a wide-ranging debate on this topic. Certainly ever since I have been in the parliament it has been the subject of many committees, and it is something on which constituents often approach me when I go out and speak in public. So the government have moved on this issue.

speech.para: It is important to note that we have asked the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, ANZFA, to consider the need for additional regulation in the food sector. That is a more appropriate way to address this issue of providing consumers with better information than by using a general act such as the Trade Practices Act to set industry specific requirements. Education is what this campaign is about. As Senator Neal has noted, we are using a rather large sum of money, $1.2 million, on a public education and awareness campaign. We do believe that this is a sensible and fair approach. It is consistent with international practice and it will maximise the opportunities that Australian consumers have to identify and buy Australian products. This can only be to the benefit of local jobs and investment.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Troeth) read a third time.

debate.para: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.

talk.start.para: —A lot of requests come to us during the sittings of the Senate to exempt bills from the cut-off motion. We have a lot of requests being put to us, especially when we have a huge workload and usually at the end of a session, in relation to exempting bills from the cut-off. When we came to this particular session in parliament, there was the assumption that there was a high possibility that the government were going to shoot themselves in the foot and put themselves and the country to a double dissolution election. The government have decided that that is not a particularly good idea and have worked out a deal to get out of something which in the end they did not wish to do. There is also a tax package which has not been released yet, and the government did make some promises about the fact that that would be released before they pushed the country to election. So the situation is that we will be back here in August and we will have the opportunity to deal with the legislation that has not been shoved through in this particular session of parliament.

speech.para: As I said, there are two elements to this request, the main one being urgency. I believe the argument in relation to urgency on the wheat bill has been unconvincing. You only have to look at the fact that it has been brought forward to see that it is not a bill that has been hanging around for several sessions in a completed form that everybody wants and that has a start-up date which has to be met or else the world will fall apart. It happens to be a bee in the bonnet of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). The problem with that bee in the bonnet is that it is not the same bee in the bonnet of other people in the industry.

Unfortunately, although there are some spokespeople from the grains councils and so on—and we will deal with these issues more fully when we come to the bill itself—the problem is that there has not been the opportunity for other models to be considered properly. I am hearing, very strongly, that there are many people on the ground who have a different opinion from the minister. Instead of pushing this forward—not just saying, `This has to be put through because it has been hanging around for a while,' but bringing forward a piece of legislation—despite the concerns of many people on the ground is not a particularly wise thing to do.

If the coalition are happy to wave goodbye to many rural and regional voters in Western Australia, that is fine. I guess they have done that on a number of other issues, whether it be trade policy or competition policy or even the issue that Senator Brown has just been talking about, truth in advertising when it comes to whether or not Australian produce is in fact Australian produce or whether it is produce bought, at high ecological and employment expense, from another part of the world because it happens to be cheaper to bring in. Whether or not such produce is of better quality or is better for our health or anything else becomes more difficult to tell with our current labelling laws. It may have been irradiated because it had to come a long way, for example. We should pursue health and food standards and standards that assist in maintaining sensible employment in rural and regional Australia. We should be creating those goods and services which Australia is good at producing but not undercutting those by rather silly means or, in this case, deception.

Here we have, again, a bill which is being pushed forward by the minister, who does not seem to want to listen to the people on the ground. He has a bee in his bonnet; he wants to corporatise and to privatise. I am very grateful that the Senate has accepted the need to review competition policy but, at the same time, we are seeing a National Party minister pushing through a proposal despite the very strong concerns of the people on the ground.

I have had very strong representations from Western Australia, but it is not confined to Western Australia. People on the ground throughout Australia are very concerned about the model, about the way this is being pushed through and about the lack of interest in looking at alternatives. We have a National Party minister from a party saying, `We are listening to the people on the ground,' yet they are not listening. All they needed to do was to table this legislation in the Senate, adjourn it to the next session and give the industry and the people on the ground time to talk it through. That is not unreasonable. It is unreasonable to suggest that this should be shoved through before people have a chance to build up steam and change the decision.

There is no logic to what is being proposed here. In my opinion, there is no reasonable argument for urgency. There is no argument that the world will fall apart if this bill does not get put through. The Senate has been extraordinarily generous in sitting this extra week, and we are being asked to sit this extra time for a bill that has been brought forward despite the deep concerns of people from my state of Western Australia and from other states as well. Even those supposedly representative organisations are not necessarily voicing the opinions of the people on the ground.

There is that wide consensus, yet it seems to me that the idea is to put this through before that wider consensus becomes a stronger voice and before they have the chance to change the proposal to meet those concerns. The coalition are never going to learn any thing about the needs and concerns of rural and regional Australia unless they actually decide to listen to what is happening on things like competition policy and to the concerns of people who say, `If it is not broke, do not fix it with something that is going to be detrimental to us and take away our role.'

The coalition seem to have a fear of anything where people have a say in the outcomes of the activities they are involved in. Whether it is community based education, community based child care or community based health, we have had funds removed from people and from organisations that speak up for themselves. Here we have the farmers saying, `Listen to us, please.' If you are going to have a piece of legislation which is, one would assume, for the benefit of wheat farmers, surely you should listen to the people who are likely to be affected.

They are telling me that they have been put under undue pressure. They have not had a chance to have their models considered. The minister has not been listening, and they are telling me that this is not an urgent bill. I am not prepared to stand here and vote for the exemption of a cut-off for a bill under these circumstances. I would urge honourable senators to listen to those people who are saying that we should give this a four-week break to let the bill sit and be talked about. Then, if it is as good as the minister believes it is, we will consider it in August. If the community believe it is a worthwhile bill with worthwhile outcomes, it will stand and be supported in August.

If that is what you are frightened of, I guess that is why you are pushing for this exemption from the cut-off now. It is an outrageous proposal in a situation where we are being asked to put an extra week into the program. The reason for that extra week was native title and the Telstra bill. This is neither native title nor the Telstra bill and we are being asked to give extra time to consider it. That is not acceptable and I will be voting against the exemption from the cut-off.

talk.start.para: —The opposition is also opposed to the exemption from the cut-off. At the outset of my remarks, I want to pick up the comments made by Senator Margetts with respect to the program of the Senate. It is correct, and I endorse Senator Margetts's remarks, that the reason the Senate is sitting this week is the sudden change that occurred following the Queensland election with respect to the native title bill. Let us all understand precisely where we are now and where we were a couple of weeks ago. A couple of weeks ago we were inexorably heading down the path towards a double dissolution. It was very likely, as has been indicated, that once this Senate and this parliament rose at the end of the winter session we might not be coming back. At that stage, the government was wallowing around trying to figure out what particular legislation it might want to get carried before the end of the session. It was not too sure about Telstra, because it did not know whether it had the numbers in the Senate, but it thought it might throw that into the list.
—This has been on the program for weeks, and you know it.

—I will deal with those issues quite happily in a moment, Senator Troeth, if you just keep quiet and listen. They also listed the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . This bill has some history to it, which I will come to in a moment. Following the Queensland election, when the Prime Minister was spooked by the results and suddenly decided that his grand plan for a double dissolution race based election was not going to produce the results that he had hoped, and following Senator Harradine's proposal to renegotiate the outcome of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , we were told in the Senate that we will probably have to sit an extra week to deal with this native title compromise. That is the reason we are here this week.

speech.para: If parliament had run its natural course, there is every likelihood that this wheat marketing legislation would not have even been dealt with prior to the Senate rising at its normal proposed time last week. I agree with Senator Margetts. The question of urgency with regard to this legislation has had more to do with the conjunction with the fact that there has been an extra week allocated to deal with native title and Telstra than anything to do with the legislation itself.

The Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is the second half of a package of legislation that was originally put and passed by this Senate late last year. When considering the legislation that the government seeks to bring before the Senate, if it gets an exemption, I find myself in a position of wanting to read out the previous speech I made when we dealt with the first part of the legislation. But I do not need to do that because it is on the Hansard. What is so fascinating is that everything that the opposition said on that occasion was absolutely correct, and we told you so. What happened last year when the government brought forward its
Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill

is that we said this legislation should not proceed at this time because there are too many unresolved issues; unresolved issues as to the company structure, unresolved issues as to the future of the single desk—

talk.start.para: —That's been resolved.

—Senator Troeth, you can keep interrupting, but what you are saying is not correct, and I will demonstrate it to you shortly. There are unresolved issues as to the application of taxation to growers' interests in the Wheat Industry Fund and their future interests with shares in the new corporate structure. There was at that time a range of unresolved issues, and there was also a lot of disquiet across the industry. Senator Woodley knows this, and Senator Margetts has referred to it. That uncertainty, that lack of agreement, still exists today.

speech.para: What we said on the last occasion would have been a far more sensible approach for the government to adopt. It should not have proceeded with its first part of the legislation late last year. Rather, it should postpone it and bring back the entire package of legislation this year. The government said, `No, we do not need to do that because what is going to happen is this: we will put through the first part of the legislation and then we will proceed to further negotiate with the industry, have those discussions and in about May this year everybody will be in the cart, they will have all agreed and then we can put the bill before the parliament and finish off the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board and so on.' That has not happened.

We have legislation before this Senate, but when was that legislation introduced into the parliament? It was introduced into the House of Representatives on 14 May. As evidence given to the Senate legislation committee shows, that was about the first time that anybody in the industry even saw this second round of legislation. The House of Representatives passed the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 on 1 June. It was then introduced into the Senate on 26 June, literally about the time the Senate was due to rise. It was the last week or so of the normal sittings of the Senate. That is when the government introduced the bill into this place.

What happened? The bill was referred by the Selection of Bills Committee to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for consideration—a quite appropriate course of action, given the uncertainty and lack of agreement that existed at that time in the industry and still exists. The Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee was put in the position of not even having time to advertise its hearing and making arrangements to have a hearing virtually within one or two days of the bill being introduced.

It was introduced on the 26th; the committee sat on the 29th. It had to get leave to sit during the sittings of the Senate. Witnesses were hurriedly advised that the hearing was on and, fortunately, the major participants were able to get to Canberra to give their evidence. The committee was put in the position of having to prepare and table a report the next day. What a way to treat legislation and the committees of this Senate! And why? Because the government thought that they were not coming back after the end of this session and they wanted to get this legislation through before the inevitable double dissolution that was then in contemplation.

When the various interests in the industry came before the Senate committee at the public hearing, they expressed serious concerns still with this legislation. It was made very clear to us as opposition members of the committee—and I am sure to Senator Woodley who was there as well—that there were very serious matters that were still not resolved to the satisfaction of all the major interests in the wheat industry. Senators would have received—as they did last year when the first round of legislation was being dealt with—correspondence from a range of grower organisations. They would have received correspondence from the Western Australian Farmers Federation dated 23 June. I would like to read part of the correspondence sent to senators. It states:

Dear Senator, This is a request from the Western Australian Farmers Federation for you to block the proposed amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act that we understand are being tabled in the Senate on Wednesday 24 June 1998.

When this bill was suddenly dropped onto the list in the parliament, the grower organisations around the country found out about it. They had not been given any prior warning or had any understanding as to when this bill was going to be dealt with.

talk.start.para: —Absolutely wrong.

—The correspondence proves it. They were ringing our offices and writing to us saying, `Hang on a minute. We have not agreed with this legislation yet. We have not agreed with all of the aspects of the restructuring. We want you to delay it.' This is certainly what the Western Australian Farmers Federation said in their letter. They go on:

speech.para: This state is uncomfortable with a number of facets of the bill, namely potential loss of the single desk from the so-called grower company in 2004 and the power granted to the minister in deciding the structure of the company.

The Minister for Primary Industries has already stated his intention to create the grower corporate model, or the company, and loss of grower control in his model is almost assured over the medium term. These two factors alone are more than sufficient reasons to oppose the bill in its current form and force the minister back to the negotiating table.

Contrary to statements by the minister, the Honourable John Anderson, the WA Farmers Federation has never formally endorsed the GCM—that is, the grower corporate model—presently before you. So his statement that it has unanimous grower support is incorrect.

Western Australian growers produce approximately 40 per cent of the nation's wheat crop and, more importantly, 60 to 65 per cent of the nation's export wheat crop. Better than 90 per cent of WA's production is exported. The minister should not impose this legislation on such a significant percentage of the nation's producers if they are opposed to it.

They go on to outline in detail their concerns about the legislation, particularly the reference to the sunset clause, their concerns about ensuring grower ownership and control in the future, issues related to the proposed memorandum and articles of association—which still have not been clarified to this date—and so on. Time does not permit me to read the entire correspondence, but at the end of the letter it says:

Until a model is produced that satisfactorily addresses the grower focused requirements outlined above, Western Australia cannot accept the minister's legislation and we urge the Senate to leave the existing legislation in place until we resolve the problem.

The position here is that the major export state for wheat in this country is saying that we still do not have a resolution of these issues and it would be better not to proceed with this legislation at this point in time. They are saying that there is no urgency to deal with it, but rather we should allow the issues to be negotiated and hopefully resolved.

We received correspondence from the New South Wales Farmers Association. Their position is interesting, because they actually do support the legislation being carried in its current form. Providing they get certain amendments that suit them, they support the legislation ultimately to be carried by the Senate. As they outlined on 22 June in correspondence, their problem is as follows:
Dear Senator, The New South Wales Farmers Association does not support the Wheat Marking Amendment Bill as it currently stands before the Senate.

Then they go on to outline their particular concerns, which no doubt will be referred to later in the debate. I acknowledge that they are happy to see the legislation proceed, but they are banking on their issues being re solved subsequent to the passage of the legislation. They acknowledged in evidence to the committee that, if their issues were not to be satisfactorily resolved, they would not support the legislation.

It should be a bit of a concern to the members of the New South Wales Farmers Association that they have this somewhat schizophrenic view that they are prepared to see the legislation passed in the expectation that their issues will be resolved, particularly their concerns with regard to taxation. In respect of this particular concern they have about taxation, my colleague Senator O'Brien asked Mr Martin, representing the New South Wales farmers:
Let me put it to you this way: would you want us then to vote for the bill if it had not been amended in that way?—
that is, amended in the way they had hoped. Mr Martin said:
If an amendment were not carried, such that it had that effect, then I would prefer the bill not to proceed.
Senator O'BRIEN —Has the government given you any assurance that they will move such amendments?
This is in relation to taxation—
Mr Martin —I have had no such assurance from the government. Because this matter was late to account, I believe that an understanding of the matter is only just coming about.
Senator O'BRIEN —Would you have senators support this bill were it not so amended?
Mr Martin —Absolutely not.

The position of the Queensland Grain Growers Association is similar. Whilst they, in principle, support carriage of the legislation, they too are still highlighting the fact that they have major concerns about the single desk and taxation. They are saying to us, `If we don't get those issues resolved, we don't want this restructured wheat board.' The problem for those organisations is going to be this: if the legislation gets carried and they do not then resolve those issues satisfactorily, they are going to be stuck with a restructured wheat industry that they themselves have said to this Senate they will not necessarily be happy with.

In all of this, we believe the most prudent course is to not grant the exemption. That would provide further time to resolve the issues that are still of major concern to the Western Australian Farmers Federation—the major wheat exporting state—and also of concern to other grain associations in the rest of the country, but particularly those in the two major states of New South Wales and Queensland.

The position of the opposition is this: we have said all along that we support, ultimately, the process of restructuring the wheat industry. In fact, we started the process when we were in government. But we have said all along, as the growers themselves have said, that it should be restructured on the basis that there is acceptance of the restructuring throughout the wheat industry. At the moment, we do not have that. At the moment, we have major grower organisations telling the Senate committee, telling members of the Senate continually, that they are not happy with the outcome, that they need more time.

On that basis, the position of the opposition is we are prepared to say the legislation should not be allowed to proceed to finality in this session. That will then give us the time to finalise these issues, and hopefully legislation brought back in the next session will have the support of all the parties in the industry and can be carried unanimously by this Senate.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats are supporting the cut-off motion but, I must say, without a lot of enthusiasm. That is because the process is a real problem and has been a problem. What Senator Forshaw and Senator Margetts have said, as far as it went, was true, but it is not the whole story. We should know the rest of the story.

speech.para: One of the real problems for a small party like the Democrats to try to achieve the best for the wheat industry in all of this has been a process which really, as Senator Forshaw has said, has been less than perfect. Let me just say on behalf of the secretariat of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee that they were put in a very difficult position in having to call witnesses and write a report in what really was an impossible time frame.

But there is more to the whole issue—that is, on this particular legislation, there are a number of different opinions, as Senator Forshaw and Senator Margetts have said, but they are coming together. That really is something that Senator Margetts and Senator Forshaw did not say, but I do believe that these opinions are starting to come together.

The real opposition to this legislation is in Western Australia. But let us put on the record that there are two farming organisations at least—one of which does support the legislation, the pastoralists and graziers, and the Western Australian Farmers Federation—which have many concerns. Let me indicate also that, of course, the Western Australian Farmers Federation supports a much larger group of grain growers in Western Australia than PGA. Nevertheless, there is division even between those peak bodies. In talking to the Western Australian Farmers Federation representatives, I got from them a number of concerns which, I believe, will be dealt with by the amendments that the Democrats are moving, and by one which I believe the government is moving, to do with the single desk operation and taxation.

In terms of the single desk, I know that the government is coming up with an amendment that the Democrats can support, but we will have to look at that as the debate proceeds. In terms of taxation, I understand that the government will not support that amendment, but again I guess that will be revealed in the debate. But I hope the Labor Party might because that then would fulfil one of the big concerns of Western Australian farmers and other groups. So we look to the Labor Party to support that amendment as being a big solution to the problems that Senator Forshaw has raised.

It is very difficult to try to represent different states in this, because there is not only a division between organisations in Western Australia but also a division between Western Australia and the other states. I believe that that is sad. I have to say to the government and to any future government that we really have to do better. We have to do much better in our consultation process in that we need to take on board all of the concerns that are being raised. It would not be so serious if we could say, `Well, it is just a few disgruntled farmers here or there.'

We are talking about divisions between state bodies, divisions within state bodies and divisions between individual farmers and the bodies who represent them. Obviously, we all have to do a better job. We are just not getting there in terms of that process. I am not going to say that I am doing the job properly. I do not know how do it. I got involved in the division in the sugar industry in Queensland and was able to do a ballot of 5,000 canefarmers, which gave us some indication, but I do not know how I could, with my resources, do a ballot of 60,000 wheat farmers in Australia.

We really have to do a lot more work. Peak bodies have to do a lot more work. They have to hear. They have to be able to take on board issues raised by significant numbers of their members or we will continue to have these kinds of divisions within industry. That really is of benefit to no-one, and it is not something we should make political capital out of because it is a concern that we all have. If there is a change of government some time in the future, that new government will have exactly the same problem. They will have to deal with these issues of how do you listen to individual farmers, how do you listen to peak bodies, how do you put in place a process which takes all of those different opinions and puts them together so that individual farmers and peak bodies can own the process.

The minister would probably say, `I have done all the consulting I can possibly do, and this is a decision of the government.' I understand that, but this is just happening too often in the wool industry, wheat industry, sugar industry—you name it. It is happening too often. Somebody or all of us have to put our heads together and come up with processes. Senator Forshaw, if Labor happens to win an election some time in the future, you are going to have exactly the same problem, and you are going to have to find a solution. Let us put that on the table as well.

The Grains Council, which is the peak body, also has problems with this legislation. They believe that if the amendments that the Democrats are moving and the government is moving now in terms of the single desk are passed then, by and large, their concerns would be met. We will see whether those amendments get through. By and large, the peak bodies that make up the Grains Council in South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland do support the position of the Grains Council. But, like Senator Forshaw, there are certainly individual farmers who are still raising concerns.

talk.start.para: —And those associations as well.

—Yes, they are, but what they are saying to me, Senator Forshaw, is that if the amendments which are now being proposed were carried, those concerns would be met. However, they would not meet all of the concerns of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. Let me indicate that I am well aware of that. I am not convinced, however, if we had a lot more time that the concerns of the Western Australian Farmers Federation could really be met within the current structure.

speech.para: I think what they are proposing is quite radically different, although they say to me that they could even live with this legislation as long as the memorandum and articles dealt with their issue. That is over to the government. I cannot influence that. It might be at that point the government needs to pick up the concerns that the Western Australian Farmers Federation are raising. Their cooperative model is one that I think deserves serious consideration. I do not know if that could be picked up, but it is over to the government on that. I cannot move an amendment to the legislation which would take account of their concerns. I note that Senator Boswell has just entered the chamber. You are needed, Ron. You are needed in this debate. I think you may have something to add.

So for these reasons, I indicate that the Democrats will support, without enthusiasm, the cut-off motion because we can see that Senator Forshaw and Senator Margetts have raised a lot of concerns. We are not con vinced that those concerns cannot be picked up within the debate on the legislation, particularly if the amendments are supported. So we are prepared to allow the debate to continue. We certainly have had strong representation from the Grains Council and the Queensland Grain Growers Association saying that they wish the legislation to be debated. They do not want it to be prevented from being debated this week. I am persuaded by that.

With some bemusement, I discovered that I had been the subject of a couple of debates in the government party room. I have been lobbied by government members on different sides of this debate. That underlines that there is a lively debate going on, but I am convinced that we can deal with that debate if we deal with this legislation. So the Democrats will support the cut-off motion.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to this motion, I want to highlight that what we are talking about in exempting the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 from the cut-off is the difference between the bill being able to be on the Notice Paper and debated today and the bill being able to be on the Notice Paper and debated in 33 days time—that is, on 10 August, which, as far as I am aware, is the next scheduled sitting day.

speech.para: That is essentially the character of the motion that we are talking about. We are talking about something like a 33-day difference. That is the first proposition that the Senate has to take into consideration. That is the practical impact of the carriage of this motion. It does not mean that if the motion is carried the Senate could not proceed to adjourn the debate on the bill, were it to come on, at any time. But, if the Senate expressed the view that the matter ought to be available to be debated now, it would be unlikely that it would be taken off the Notice Paper.

The other possibility would be that the government decide they wanted to take it off the Notice Paper at some stage during the debate. That might happen, were it to be the case that, for example, the Grains Council or one of the constituent organisations of the Grains Council withdrew their support for the legislation if they were to find that it was not amended in some way that they had a commitment to. They are the possibilities that we are faced with in relation to the question of whether this legislation should be exempted from the cut-off and allowed to be debated, potentially, today.

When I spoke to officers of the Grains Council about what was going to happen to this legislation, the view put to me was that there was a concern that if this bill was not debated last week or the week before—because we were not at that stage going to sit this week—there was a possibility, which everyone was concerned about, that the parliament would not resume in August; that there would be an election called; that the bill which had been passed by the House of Representatives would lapse; that at some stage the parliament would resume; and that there was a question as to whether this legislation would then be re-presented in a timely fashion. The Grains Council raised the issue of whether it would be some time next year before this legislation could come back before the parliament.

That was probably a concern which had some validity at that time. However, since the Queensland election, it became clear that there was a distinct possibility that the very grounds that the government has been relying upon—indeed, felt compelled, it appeared, to act upon—to call a double dissolution were likely to disappear. This morning, those grounds have disappeared; that is, the Wik legislation has been passed by the Senate in a form that is, according to all the information that the government has given us, acceptable to the government. So it would appear that there is not going to be a double dissolution election and, therefore, it would appear—given that I do give the government some credit for good sense—that they are not going to now dissolve the parliament and call an election so that we do not return in August, because they have just gone through a process, apparently, to avoid that eventuality.

talk.start.para: —They were celebrating last week.
—Senator Sherry says that there were parties taking place, they were celebrating last week, that there was an agreement on Wik which would obviate the need for a double dissolution election.
—They've had a stay of execution, have they?
—It was on TV. It was the lead item on the ABC.

—I am happy for the confirmation from senators that that is the case because, as Senator Sherry says, this was on television. Perhaps Senator Troeth will tell us that there was an entirely different matter being celebrated.
—Your demise—that's what.

—I would be interested, if you revisit that matter a little later, to hear how you think that is going to occur. In relation to this legislation, as I said at the beginning of my remarks, if this motion is not carried, the government can have this bill placed on the Notice Paper on 10 August, which is about 33 days away.

speech.para: The basis on which the Senate ought to consider this matter is not whether the government wants the bill exempted from the cut-off now, because I do not think that is good policy, but whether there is good reason for this bill to be exempted from the cut-off. What is the reason? The only reason that has been put to me by anyone is the double dissolution factor.

I think there is another reason that is in people's minds which has not been expressed as to why they want this bill out of the way. The reason was touched on by Senator Forshaw and Senator Margetts, that is, there is a package of measures which clearly is not entirely agreed at this stage; nevertheless, that package is represented in the bill which we are discussing.

The Western Australian Farmers Federation are saying that they do not want this package. There has been a bit of argy-bargy in that organisation as to whether their views were properly represented in the Grains Council. The evidence given to the Senate committee inquiry was that the Western Australian Farmers Federation representative had no authority to sign up to the package of meas ures now reflected in the bill. The representative was, in fact, instructed to get the authority of the Western Australian Farmers Federation before signing up. It was alleged that that representative did sign up to the package and was party to a press release by the Grains Council which supported the package of measures which is reflected in the bill before the parliament today, the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , and certain other measures which relate to the memorandum and article of association of the new Australian Wheat Board Ltd and the structure of the three companies that are to be reflected in this legislation.

The Western Australian Farmers Federation are now agitating against the package and saying they do not support this model at all. They support a cooperative model, quite a different model. I think it is fair to say that they have been pursuing their view with various senators—with me, Senator Forshaw, Senator Woodley, Senator Margetts, who is nodding, and I am sure with the government. There is an argument within the industry about that model. I have to say that it may be that that argument will not be resolved. Certainly it is the case that pastoralists and graziers support the legislation in its current form.

I am not in a position to say what the numerical basis of the two organisations is, but it has been suggested to me—and I think Senator Woodley said as much—that the Western Australian Farmers Federation has a much stronger representative basis in the wheat growing industry in Western Australia. But I want to say this: the pastoralists and graziers do not support the amendments to this bill proposed by the government, if I understand the submission that they presented to the Senate committee. The pastoralists and graziers do not support the single desk. They believe it should be an entirely free market. The government has acceded to pressures from the industry in Western Australia and elsewhere on the question of ensuring that the single desk does not lapse, effectively, in 2004, as is contained in the legislation in its current form. The government proposed amendments to remove the effective sunset ting of the single desk after they were pressured by a significant number of organisations.

The position on the tax treatment of the wheat industry funds is not resolved. Senators heard Senator Forshaw talk about some of the evidence before the committee as to the position of certain representative organisations of grain growers from different states on the question of what their attitude to the legislation will be if the bill is not amended in a way suitable to them. I take that to mean if the bill is not amended to ensure that at least the earnings on WIF funds—if not also the capital value of the Australian Wheat Board, as represented in the ultimate value of Australian Wheat Board B-class shares—are treated as active assets for rollover purposes subsequent to the legislation.

My understanding of the position of the New South Wales Farmers Association on this matter is that, if that proposition is not acceded to, they will not support the passage of the bill. My understanding of the position of the Western Australian Farmers Federation is the same—that they will not support the bill if it is not amended in such a form. The Grains Council, when questioned at the committee, were not able to say what their position was. I took that to mean that the officers at the table were not confident that they could give an answer to the committee which would be borne out by a decision of that body. In other words, the Grains Council's position on that matter was not clear enough for them to tell the committee, one way or the other, what the attitude of the Grains Council of Australia would be if the legislation were not amended in that fashion.

talk.start.para: —And what's your position going to be?

—The position of the opposition? I am quite happy to deal with that, Senator, and I will come to that. In relation to the time frame of this legislation, you have heard that the bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 15 May. The drafting instructions for this bill were issued at the beginning of April. In fact, it was circulated to the Grains Council in draft form on 28 April. It was passed by the House of Representatives think on 1 June, and introduced into the Senate on 26 June.

speech.para: I have dealt with the timetable for the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee to deal with this matter in relation to the motion to print its report on the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . To summarise that, it is clear that the committee did not have a reasonable time to give consideration to this matter, given that we are talking about one of Australia's major export industries—an industry with sales of billions of dollars a year which affects the livelihoods of thousands of farmers in Australia and thousands of their employees.

This is a serious issue. This is an issue which I think warrants a further 33 days of consideration. The reality is that consideration of this matter by the Senate would be enhanced by that further consideration. As Senator Woodley said, this is an impossible time frame. This is a time frame which is more likely than not to give rise to measures which will need to be revisited—if, indeed, they can be.

One of the things I am concerned about in questioning the department and representatives of the Grains Council about the grower corporate model that is reflected in this legislation—the new corporatised Australian Wheat Board—is that there is no fall-back position, that this is the position the industry must go on with. If there is an error in this formulation, there is no plan to correct it. There must, therefore, be ultimate confidence in this package by the government and by the council. And I hope, if the legislation is passed, that their confidence is borne out.

I am concerned that the evidence before the committee is that there is not a fall-back position, that there is no escape clause—that this is it. We are making changes to this perfect model apparently on the run and there are issues that remain outstanding. I am doubtful that Senator Woodley can be confident that, as he puts it, the different opinions are coming together. They appear to be, to me at least, as far apart as they were when this legislation appeared. The issues are as stark. The only matter that appears likely to be resolved is the issue of the single desk, and there are still some grey issues about that.

On the question of the tax amendment, the opposition has informed the Grains Council that we will not be supporting Senator Woodley's amendment. The opposition believes that the treatment of the WIF contributions, together with an amount to reflect the depreciation value, not being treated as taxable assets—in other words, they have been deducted without the deduction of tax and they will be recoverable through the B-class share sale as non-taxable assets; that is the position, as we understand it, that has been reported to the committee—is quite an advantageous position for grain growers and we would not be supporting amendments to improve upon that position. We will deal with that further in the debate on the matter. I believe the government understood our position to be that.

It would appear, unless the government changes its position, that Senator Woodley's amendments will not carry. That leaves us not knowing what the Grains Council's position would be. I assume the New South Wales Farmers Association will withdraw their support for the legislation. I do not know if that is the case. They may change their position again. It just goes to show that we are dealing with this legislation on the run. If this motion is not carried, then the government will be able to introduce the legislation on 10 August and we would have a further 33 days to give consideration to these matters and refine them.

Given that I agree with Senator Woodley in that the committee and all parties have had an impossible time frame to meet, I am rather concerned that we are trying to sweep this matter out of the way so that all those people who have been involved for years can say, `Oh, thank goodness this is over, we can get on with something else,' irrespective of whether we end up with the correct package or not. I urge the Democrats to reconsider their position and to vote against the motion exempting this legislation from the cut-off. What is lost by that is 33 days. What is lost by them taking the alternative position we do not know, but it might be a lot worse.

talk.start.para: —The Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 would seem to be not the most preferred option. The industry is still negotiating. What is the haste? Is it related to something needing to be debated in here which may take a bit of time so that they can avoid the Telstra issue for a bit longer?
—No, that's not it.

—That is not it. That is another matter the bush is very concerned about. It is quite apparent from the correspondence and from the evidence given to the committee that industry will not vigorously oppose this. They have preferred options. They would prefer further consultation and further negotiation. This is coming from a government that is supposed to be the friend of this group. When you see so many differing opinions, you wonder what consultation has taken place and whether it has been adequate.

speech.para: As Senator Woodley has said, he expects that a compromise will be reached in the near future. Why then are we debating the bill now? Why is it not being allowed to wait for an additional 33 days for the industry to continue its negotiations, to work out the best option for the whole of the industry and for the whole of Australia? I do not know what the situation is. I hope that negotiations and discussions will continue with the industry after the legislation is passed. When we come back here we will again be told that this is urgent legislation.

If the government had got it right in the first place, we would not be facing this prospect. There are rumours in the corridors now that we will be back here next week. The reason for coming back repeatedly is obviously that the government is not getting through its negotiations and consultation processes accurately and adequately. After the consultation and negotiation processes have been completed, we will have to come back and do it again. That does not lead to certainty in the industry or to good government and good legislation. This is something this government has to think seriously about. This year, as the good season continues, we will have a good crop in many areas, particularly in New South Wales.

But the government has still not completed its consultation with the industry as to what is the best marketing or selling method. We know the industry prefers single desk, but it is imperative that this government actually undertakes constructive and meaningful consultation and brings in legislation after that consultation has been completed. It is not happening here. I would wager anything that we are of—

talk.start.para: —What about the National Party?
—The National Party, I notice, are not even in here. They are probably out there trying to screw a deal on Telstra.
—Are they here supporting their minister? It doesn't look like it.

—That is absolutely correct, Senator Margetts. I should not pick up interjections, that is disorderly, but it is well worth noting that the National Party are not present in this debate. I hope they are going to speak later on in the debate because they claim to be the ones who represent the country areas—but one has to seriously wonder. I know the Liberal Party will tell me they have more seats in rural areas than the National Party. The senior partner in the coalition—
—We are a coalition.

—Yes, Senator, but some of those coalitions can falter. What we have to see with this bill is a coalition of the grain industry, the wheat industry, across this country. Because situations do vary from state to state—New South Wales and Western Australia would be the two largest producers of grain, but wheat is produced in other states—there has to be a coalition of agreement as to what is best for the industry as a nation, too. The coalition of political parties that forms this government does not appear to be taking notice of what the coalition of the grain industry, or the wheat industry, would appear to be trying to drive at. I think the government is to be roundly condemned for this. For 13 years, they would allege that we did not consult, but I would have thought this was one of their own core constituencies.

speech.para: A number of letters and a number of submissions were received by the committee in its hasty consultation process. It was forced into a situation where, whilst not opposing the legislation outright, it was very apparent that it was not the preferred legislation of the industry.

This industry is vitally important to this country. It is a large export earner for this country. I would have thought that it was incumbent upon the government to ensure that it got the best results, the best piece of legislation. It does not seem that this will possibly be the case in this situation. Industry participation, industry involvement, is essential if you are going to get good legislation. That does not seem to be what is happening here.

Whilst I do not intend to take long, I think it is important, and I cannot reiterate it enough, that the government undertake this consultation, that they get the best piece of legislation. Instead of having to debate this two or three times, if they had done it properly, we would have only had to have debated this once, and it might have even gone through as non-controversial on a Thursday at lunchtime—that should have been the ultimate goal, the ultimate aim, of this government because that would have then meant that the consultation process undertaken by the government with the industry would have been significant and meaningful to the industry. The industry would not have had to come and write to the opposition; it would not have had to lobby the Greens and the Democrats to ensure that some of the amendments were moved.

Very clear indications were given that the industry was not totally happy with this piece of legislation. It is not their most preferred option; it is one they can live with. But should we be introducing in this country legislation that people can live with, but that they would rather they did not have to? In fact, if another 33 days had been taken, in all probability the industry would have got the legislation that it wanted. It would have then been able to go ahead with certainty, knowing that its needs were going to be met well into the future. Now, it continues to be faced with uncertainty, with cut-in dates and cut-out dates, and not with its most preferred option.

We need to give our rural industries certainty. We need to listen to their needs. We need to listen to their demands. Being realistic, maybe you cannot meet all of their demands, but it is vitally important that they be given the opportunity to try to reach consensus through a consultation process. By forcing this bill through, to exempt it from the cut-off, that is not going to be able to be done.

I will wager you, as I said before, that we will be back here discussing, and maybe amending, this legislation next time around, presumably, again, towards the end of a sitting session so they can try to use that as a pressure mechanism to get agreement on all sides. That is not the way that legislation should be working. Legislation needs to be carefully thought out. It needs consultation. That is not happening, and the government is to be condemned.

I will finish by saying that I have grave reservations about the way this has been handled by the government. It could have been better handled. I am surprised that they have treated one of their core constituent groups in such a manner; that they have basically ignored and disregarded their need to obtain, or to come to a negotiated settlement on, the best piece of legislation for the industry. It is a good industry, it is a productive industry, and we should be giving it the best legislative chances to continue to be so.
