talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the minister recall the apprehension of the vessel, Aliza Glacial , on 21 October last year for illegally fishing for Patagonian toothfish in Australia's exclusive economic zone near Heard Island in the Southern Ocean? Does he also recall the government patting itself on the back and calling the operation an outstanding success and a lesson to foreign vessels that illegal fishing in the EEZ would not be tolerated? Is it true that no penalties have been paid by the vessel's owners for the trespassing offence and that the government has allowed a Norwegian bank to repossess the vessel? Is it further true that the government is liable for the costs associated with this fiasco? If so, what are those costs?

—I thank Senator Murphy for that question. The Senate will recall that the Howard government did dispatch the HMAS Anzac to Heard and Macdonald Islands in October 1997. The Anzac arrested two foreign vessels allegedly fishing illegally in the area. They were the Salvora and the Aliza Glacial and, subsequently, the Big Star was arrested. A Norwegian bank, Bergenspanken ASA, holds the mortgage over the Aliza Glacial and has taken action to secure that debt, including through the arrest of the vessel. The Australian Government Solicitor has filed an application in the Federal Court to secure the vessel and is taking every measure to ensure that criminal proceedings prevail over the civil action taken by the mortgagor.

answer.para: On 14 May 1998, counsel for the Australian Fisheries Management Authority made submissions to the Federal Court in relation to making any sale of Aliza Glacial subject to the continuing rights of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority. The Federal Court has reserved its decision.

The Senate will understand that it is not possible for me to comment immediately on these allegations—that is, in regard to whether that has occurred. However, I have directed the department to seek urgent advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the documents and how they may relate to the current court proceedings. I point out that the government is totally committed to protecting our fisheries resources through the EEZ, including the subantarctic. The navy has arrested three foreign fishing vessels so far in daring operations in distant and harsh conditions.

I have a warning for all illegal foreign fishing vessels. They will never know if the trail of smoke on the horizon or a blip on the radar screen is one of their illegal fishing mates or an Australian navy frigate coming to arrest them. I also point out that I heard just in recent days that the skipper and one other person did not appear before the court proceedings. If that does not occur within six months, the government automatically acquires the vessel.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. With regard to the application by the Bergenspanken, which has been made under admiralty rules, given that it is likely that the Bergenspanken will succeed in securing the vessel, can the minister inform the Senate what steps the government will be taking to ensure that in future we are not confronted with this sort of situation?

—All I can respond to in that question is the fact that this information was brought to the attention of myself and Senator Brown by the Tasmanian Conservation Trust. This matter has been, as I indicated, referred to the Attorney-General's Department—the particular documents that were given by the conservation foundation and how they might relate to the current court proceedings.

—My question is to the leader of the government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Is the minister aware of a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald that an Indonesian businessman, Mr William Soeryadjaya, paid the former Prime Minister Mr Paul Keating more than $US6 million for his half share in a piggery? Is this consistent with Mr Keating's advice to the Registrar of Members' Interests on 31 March 1994 stating that he had sold his interest to a Mr Achilles Constantinidis and associated companies? What implications does such a revelation have for the current disclosure requirements? I also ask whether the government will take action to ensure that similar episodes do not occur in the future?

—Yes, I did read this extraordinary article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, which told us a lot about the way in which the former Prime Minister Mr Keating conducted his business affairs. It also told us a little about the way in which he treated his responsibilities to the parliament. What it demonstrates is the amazing hypocrisy of Labor Party members. For months they have been coming in here and attacking Senator Parer, arguing in the finest of ways, on occasions, that he did not make full disclosure in accordance with the rules of this place. The finest of arguments have been put to suggest that the—
—Small. Weeny.

—Yes. The finest arguments, as in narrow arguments, have been put. Technical arguments have been put—Senator Ray has excelled at it—to demonstrate that Senator Parer has in some way technically breached the obligations of this place and that, for that, he should pay the ultimate penalty. Week after week, the Labor Party has come in here and said, `We demand the highest standards of accountability to the parliament.' That is what the Labor Party has said. Yet what we learn today is that—

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, only a short time ago, Senator Cook, sold his interest in his piggery companies to an Indonesian businessman, Mr Soeryadjaya. But did he disclose that he sold it to the Indonesians? No. His return to the register suggested that he sold it to his former partner.

answer.para: Did the register also tell us that, in fact, he retained the right to purchase back his interest? No, of course it did not. Why did he not tell us that, as Prime Minister of Australia, he was selling off his business interests to Indonesians? Because, of course, that would be politically embarrassing. So what he did was apparently mislead the House of Representatives into believing, by his public statement, that he had sold it to his former business partner. But, according to the Sydney Morning Herald, he apparently implied he sold it for a lot less than what he ultimately got.

Madam President, if you read the House of Representatives standing orders, you will find that that deliberate and wilful misleading amounts to a serious contempt. I can remem ber that it wasn't long ago that—isn't it interesting how quiet they are?—

talk.start.para: —Yes!
—Shouting only a few weeks ago—

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Only a few weeks ago, Senator Ray booming across the chamber, `Senator Hill you have seriously—'

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Hill—
—Yes, Madam President.
—Senator Hill, it is not appropriate to incite breaches of the standing orders.
—Talk about throw out a hook and see what you catch, Madam President.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Now we're getting a bit of life in the place. Anyway, on the basis of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald , not only did Mr Keating mislead the House of Representatives in his return but he very seriously misled it. Furthermore, he obviously did it because it would have been political embarrassing for him to have told the truth. In those circumstances, what hypocrisy it is for the Labor Party to come in here and accuse anybody of not failing to disclose in full in accordance with the Senate's terms and rules.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. How many formal decisions has the minister made in relation to the operations of the mining company, Energy Resources of Australia Pty Ltd, since he became a minister in March 1996? How many specific decisions has the minister made in relation to ERA's application to mine uranium at Jabiluka?

—In direct answer to the questions raised by Senator Chris Evans: first of all, I declared ERA as a proponent for an environmental impact assessment. You might recall, Madam President, that, prior to coming into government, we had a policy of getting rid of the absolutely stupid, ridiculous, lampooned three-mines uranium policy, which only came about because of the left wing of the Labor Party.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Alston and Senator Carr!

—I remind you, Madam President, the height of hypocrisy was that, while they had this so-called three-mines uranium policy, it didn't stop them—did it, Madam President?—from supporting the expansion of Olympic dam simply because it helped the then Labor Premier of South Australia. What utter hypocrisy!

answer.para: We got rid of the three-mines policy. We made the point from the beginning that it was not a matter of picking winners; that there was a market out there and that it was for people to go through the proper processes and do it. The company did go through a proper environmental impact assessment process which took close to two years—that is my understanding. As a result of that, I received back from Senator Hill a series of recommendations which we added to, to make them more stringent.

That is exactly what has occurred with them. There are other uranium mines—I think there is Honeymoon, Beverley and Kintyre—which have indicated that they would like to go ahead. They have been declared as proponents to go through environmental impact assessments.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question, Madam President, although I am not sure that the minister answered the question I put to him. Perhaps he would prefer to take it on notice. I asked how many formal decisions he had made in relation to ERA, particularly related to Jabiluka. Also perhaps he could advise how many of those decisions on Jabiluka are of a process nature—such as environmental, construction, milling, transport or expert controls—and how many decisions are determinative, such as a grant of lease or permission to mine. If the minister can't provide the answer today, perhaps he could take the question on notice and provide that information.

—Madam President, you wonder how, after 13 years in government, they really don't understand the processes. Export controls are only issued just prior to shipment. I could not help but notice how deliberately all over the place the Labor Party is in regard to the development of the Jabiluka mine. We had, I think, Mr Kerr making statements just recently when they were questioned about what he intended to do and he said, `Is the Labor Party saying—?' What he was saying was that they will stop the mine unless the mine is in operation and all approvals are granted. No-one believes that, least of all the Australian Greens, Senator Brown. It is really tongue in cheek, having two bob each way while they are going around pandering to the—

—On a point of order, Madam President: I asked a direct question, both in the original and in the supplementary, to the minister. I am happy for him to debate the issue at the taking note stage, but I would like an answer to the question about how many decisions he has taken and the nature of those decisions.
—There is no point of order.
—I answered that earlier. I am happy to do it again if you want to hear it repeated again. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Hill as the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the story in today's Sydney Morning Herald regarding the secret millions made by Paul Keating on the sale of his half-interest in a piggery. Is it a fact that, despite Paul Keating selling his piggery interests for at least $US6 million—as revealed in Sydney Morning Herald today—the amount on which tax and other duties were paid was only $A600,000? What implications would this have for the Commonwealth and what actions will the government take to ensure that its revenue is fully protected?
—Madam President, that would—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The question is directed to Senator Hill.

—It is interesting, because the second method of attack, the second target, on Senator Parer in recent months has been that, because his family operated a family trust, he is a tax cheat. Week after week, Labor has come in here and accused Senator Parer of tax rorting because his family operated a family trust. There is no evidence of any tax avoidance whatsoever, no evidence of any illegality, but it is good enough for Labor to throw mud in the hope that a little bit of it would stick.

answer.para: It is suggested in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning that the affairs of the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, are much more complicated in that regard. It is said that on the public record he got $600,000, yet in actual fact he received over $6 million. One might wonder why someone would get paid $6 million for a business investment that had a debt of $13 million. That might be a little puzzling. But what is being suggested in the Sydney Morning Herald is that there has not been full disclosure on this particular matter.

Has that upset the Labor Party? I wonder what internal actions they have taken today when that sort of suggestion is made about their former Prime Minister, until very recently the Leader of the Australian Labor Party. Nothing, of course, because that is different. A serious allegation on their side should be pushed aside, kept under the table. There should be no inquiry into that. Can you imagine Senator Ray getting to his feet and demanding action; can you imagine him demanding a full investigation? Can you imagine him getting up and calling Mr Keating a tax cheat? Of course not. He would say that there is not enough evidence. Why didn't he adopt the same standards in relation to Senator Parer? Because Senator Parer is on this side of the chamber. It is as simple as that: double standards and hypocrisy.

Very strange circumstances are revealed in today's Sydney Morning Herald in relation to the business affairs of Mr Keating. I presume there is an explanation for these extraordinary circumstances. I believe that, if he was paid over $6 million by an Indonesian businessman for his interest, he must have had something of value in excess of $6 million. I assume that. Otherwise, one would have some very serious questions to ask.

But my point is not so much that but what it tells you about the Australian Labor Party when they have got a problem on their side as compared to this side. They stand up here without a blush to say, `All we are interested in is principle, not the individual.' `We won't attack the man,' say the Australian Labor Party. This demonstrates again the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party in this regard. If they were genuine, if they really did seek to demonstrate high public standards, they would apply it to their own former Prime Minister rather than to others in the parliamentary process.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question which follows on from the minister's answer. Given that there are serious consequences involved there, what are the consequences, for example, in relation to capital gains tax if the amount that was declared was in fact not the price at which these assets actually changed hands?

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I believe that, if you were consistently making a judgment about questions asked in question time, the original question that Senator O'Chee asked would have been ruled out of order by you. But I ask you how on earth, if you are going to make consistent rulings in relation to supplementary questions and questions that are in order in question time, you can direct the minister to answer this supplementary question. With respect, I think it is out of order and ought to be ruled as such. I think the primary question was out of order and I am surprised you did not rule that out of order. On this occasion I do not think there is any question—

—There is no point of order. Senator Faulkner, you challenged the original question. You did that as an interjection during the question. The original question was clearly in order. The question to the minister was how was the government going to protect its revenue base, and that is a totally proper question to be asked of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I call Senator Hill.

—Not once can I remember Senator Faulkner getting up and objecting to questions from his side to Senator Parer suggesting that Senator Parer was behaving improperly in relation to taxation—not once. So why does he do it in relation to Mr Keating? Simply because it is referring to the Australian Labor Party, because it has demonstrated the double standards—
—The point is that Alston consistently has taken points of order. You talk about double standards; don't you talk about double standards to me.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, cease interjecting. I am entitled to hear the answer.

—It demonstrated the real attitude of the Australian Labor Party to not only parliamentary standards, but also prime ministerial standards. When it is on their side, it is to be covered up, kept under the table. When it is on the coalition side, they have a national responsibility to bring it out and drive it home, even if it is baseless. That is the point. That is the distinction that we are witnessing today. All Australians will be treated equally under the taxation laws, and so they should be.

—My question is also to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and, given his new-found desire to get at the facts, it is entirely appropriate. Why won't the minister table the letter sent by the Prime Minister to ministers in August 1997 outlining the restrictions on ministers and their staff in relation to the purchase of Telstra shares? Why was the minister prepared to selectively outline some of the contents of the letter in the Senate yesterday in answer to a question on Monday by Senator Ray but not table the entire text? Isn't it a fact that the Prime Minister's directive applied not only to ministers themselves but also to trusts, nomi nees and other proxy style arrangements? Will the minister now undertake to table a generic copy of the letter sent to ministers in August 1997?

—I am not sure what a generic copy of the letter is, but the point is that the question that was asked by Senator Ray related to certain matters and I answered from the letter in relation to those matters. The letter refers to other matters that were not within his question, and that is why I did not table the letter in full.

answer.para: Again, I welcome the opportunity from Senator Cook to explore what this is really all about: why the Labor Party has some political objective or is seeking some political gain out of what they claim to be conflicts of interest. They are doing it against a background of perhaps the greatest conflict of interest in the history of the Australian democracy, which was on their side only a few years ago.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The then Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, ran this piggery business—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—He ran this piggery business and apparently sold at least some of his interests to Indonesian businessmen for a sum without giving the full story. According to the Sydney Morning Herald , he retained an interest. He sold his first element of it in March 1994—

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Surely, given that Senator Hill has been asked a specific question in relation to a letter the Prime Minister sent on Telstra shares, it is proper for you presiding in the Senate to draw the minister's attention to the question and direct him to answer it.

—You know that I cannot direct him to answer the question as you want it answered. I am entitled to expect that he will answer the question that has been put to him as he sees appropriate. I cannot direct him to give the answer that you want.
—The issue is ministerial standards—
—You were trying to cover up, weren't you?
—Senator Carr!

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I respect what you say, that you cannot ask him to answer as we would want, but surely you can ask him to answer the question that was put. The question that was put was: is it not a fact that the Prime Minister's directive applied not only to ministers themselves but also to trusts, nominees and other proxy style arrangements? That is a clear question. And will he now table a copy of the letter? Surely he can answer those two very simple questions.
—Senator Hill is clearly dealing with the substance of the questions that have been—
—Senator Alston, if you do not cease interjecting, I shall deal with you.

—Senator Ray asked me certain questions about whether a letter in August required certain actions on behalf of ministers in relation to the Telstra matter. I believe that, yesterday, I answered the questions that he asked. If Senator Cook is asking me to go back and explore that letter in terms of the question he has asked today, then I will do that as well.
—Table it.
—As to why I did not table the letter, I have already answered that.
—What are you covering up?

—I said it did not only deal with the question that Senator Ray asked. I answered Senator Ray's question of yesterday. Madam President, why is Senator Cook asking me this question? It is because they think they can make some political gain out of the issue of ministerial standards. What I am suggesting is that the last political party in the world that is justified in trying that is the Australian Labor Party.

answer.para: The Australian Labor Party cannot come in here with a straight face today and talk about ministerial standards when the Sydney Morning Herald suggests that perhaps the greatest conflict of interest has been rorted on the Australian people by Mr Keating who, until recently, was their party leader and Prime Minister. That is the point that I am making relevant to the question, Senator Faulkner. If you have no credit in asking the question, I am suggesting you ought to keep sitting in your seat and stop blushing on the issue.

We on this side of the chamber will match ministerial standards against the ALP any day, and we will hold up the Sydney Morning Herald article of today as proof of our case. This article is an embarrassment for the ALP. It suggests that the former Prime Minister kept his hands in this piggery long after he disclosed to the House of Representatives that he had got rid of his interest; that he had retained a right to buy back his interest. In fact, a year after he disclosed to the House of Representatives that he had sold his interest, he was still negotiating for more money from the Indonesians. Against that background this opposition has no credibility. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill asked, in his answer, why I am asking for the letter to be tabled. It is because it is a matter of public interest. The Prime Minister has boasted high ministerial standards in this country. He directs his ministers to do certain things. It is a matter of public interest that we see what it was that he asked and whether the ministers have complied. If you will not table the letter, will the minister at least confirm the extracts from the Prime Minister's letter, quoted in the media today:

question.para: `It would not be acceptable for ministers, parliamentary secretaries and staff to purchase shares in the name of a spouse, other family member, or a nominee or trust.'
Will you at least confirm that as an accurate statement, Minister?

talk.start.para: —It came out of the Sydney Morning Herald .

—I am glad that Senator Ray gives credibility to the Sydney Morning Herald because, as I said, he ought to be blushing in this place today. I will recheck the letter, Senator Cook. But the point was, as I recall it, that the minister could not act in his own right and he could not allow someone else to act as his proxy. I think I said that to Senator Ray yesterday. But that does not in any way affect what I have been arguing, which Senator Ray seems to be acknowledging now, that the standards are on both sides. If you are trying to match the standard demonstrated by Mr Keating against that of Senator Parer, Senator Parer wins out overwhelmingly.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Senator Herron. What is the government's response to recent research conducted by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and others, which shows clearly that a lot fewer health dollars are spent on Aboriginal people compared to non-Aboriginal people? For example, they found that, for every Medicare dollar spent on non-indigenous Australians, the government spends only 27c on Aboriginal people. For every dollar spent by the government on specialist consultations for non-indigenous people, only 12c is spent on Aboriginal people. Even when all the targeted health services are added in, such as Aboriginal health services, the Commonwealth is still spending, on average, $276 less per head on indigenous Australians than on other Australians. Minister, what do you plan to do to address this unfair and unequal treatment of Aboriginal people?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lees for the question, and I acknowledge Senator Lees' interest in health care in general which she has conducted for at least eight years that I am aware of. The Commonwealth has taken a very constructive approach to the problems of Aboriginal health. Senator Lees would not be aware that I have the document in front of me that she referred to. It is a very good publication by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. I will read from the introduction:

answer.para: Australia is one of the healthiest countries in the world, and Australians are becoming even healthier. This is shown by declining death rates, increasing life expectancy, a low rate of life threatening infectious diseases and, for most people, ready access to health care when needed. But there is still room for improvement, and good health is not enjoyed by all, and the health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples is poor by any standard.

This morning I was present at a meeting in Sydney of all the state health ministers and all the ministers for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, together with Dr Michael Wooldridge, to discuss this very problem that Senator Lees has mentioned. This is the first time this has occurred in the last three years at least. We acknowledge that there are disparities. One of the problems that came out this morning is the aspect of data collection. There is not good national health statistics overall. For example, reliable data on indigenous deaths are available only to the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia.

To come to the question of disparity in health care funding, that data came from a report commissioned by Dr Wooldridge's department, and the report was based on 1995-96 data which states that health expenditure on Aboriginal people was then higher by approximately eight per cent in comparison to expenditure for other Australians. That data has to be put in context. Expenditure on indigenous peoples' health is the same as that for other Australians of similar socioeconomic status. For example, it is fairly easy to relate that the provision of health care in remote communities is, in many regards, minimal. There are no hospitals, there are no facilities available, so consequently, very few funds are spent there.

Like other people on low incomes, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people rely much more on publicly provided hospital and community health services. They carry a heavier burden of illness and have a lower life expectancy than other Australians. Aboriginal people experience greater rates of disease. For example, as Senator Lees knows, diabetes is 12 to 17 times higher than for other Australians. In that same report you will see that, in an analysis of the United States and premature mortality, 50 per cent of premature mortality was attributed to unhealthy behaviour and lifestyles, 20 per cent to human biology, 20 per cent to the physical environment and 10 per cent to inadequate health care. I think that data has to be analysed in that respect too.

A high proportion of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population live in remote areas, where providing health service, on the other hand, is more costly than in urban areas. Even though total health expenditure for Aboriginal people does vary from other Australians, indigenous people's access to Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is estimated to be about a quarter of other Australians—again because of the lack of availability of those benefits.

Progress is being made in improving the health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. For example, infant mortality rates for the indigenous population has improved. Evidence from New Zealand and North America indicates that improvements in indigenous health were realised by establishing and maintaining a level of health care services over a long period of time, and that is what the government is doing. We are approaching it constructively with the states. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, looking at infant mortality rates in particular, as you have just mentioned, is it not correct that it is the spending through specific Aboriginal health services that is making that difference? Considering that there is a total shortfall of around $97 million on Aboriginal health spending compared to the spending for the rest of us at Commonwealth level, are you prepared to stand up to those in the community arguing for a withdrawal of Aboriginal specific services, arguing that Aboriginal people have too much and should be brought back to where the rest of us are, and defend Aboriginal health services and commit to putting more money into them?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to say that we are actually putting more money into health services. In particular, we announced a further $72.6 million over four years in the 1998-99 budget. So we are spending more on health care specifically in indigenous services than has been spent by previous governments. In that, there is $42 million over the next four years to provide additional resources.

answer.para: Three days ago I was in Broome, and I linked up with the Karma Medical Service and the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service. They have developed a CD-ROM for the education of indigenous health workers. That is one of the big progressive moves that we have done as a government, as Dr Wooldridge has, to get more funding to indigenous health workers so that they can get it at that level where they are meeting with communities, going to health education and then training the health workers. I am pleased to say that, of all the workers that have come through that program, 90 per cent are employed within their own communities. I believe that is the way of the future; that Aboriginal people will teach other Aboriginal people the basics of health care. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the minister acknowledge that the Prime Minister's letter of August last year explicitly prohibited the purchase of Telstra shares by ministers and their staff for 90 days following the float? Did the minister bring that letter to the attention of his staff? Did his staff comply with the terms of that letter? What steps did the minister take to ensure that his staff complied?

—If Senator Faulkner cared to look at the answer I gave yesterday in question time, he would have noticed that I gave the answer to most of those questions. However, because he is not that bright, I will repeat it. I quote from yesterday's Hansard :

answer.para: The Prime Minister did write to ministers in August 1997 pointing out that ministers directly involved in the Telstra sale should not buy shares in Telstra at all. Other ministers were advised not to buy shares for 90 days after the first day of trading. Spouses and children could buy shares at any time, provided they were acting independently and not merely as a proxy . . .

Madam President, I went on further to point out other things but that is not the question that Senator Faulkner asked, and I am not going to repeat them. The answer to your question is yes, Senator, I did draw it to the attention of my staff.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that his media adviser, Mr Baudino, purchased 1,600 Telstra shares in his own name on 25 November 1997 in defiance of the Prime Minister's prohibition, and apparently in defiance of the fact that you brought this matter to the attention of your staff?
—I am unaware of that.
—My question also goes to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Madam President, you will remember—
—Order! This question is being directed to Senator Parer. Senator Tambling. Start again, please, Senator Brown.
—Thank you, Madam President. My question—
—Order! I need to hear this question and so does Senator Parer. Senators on my right will cease interjecting.
—The minister will remember the Prime Minister giving an ironclad guarantee—
—Order! Senators on my right will cease chattering. Senator Parer is entitled to hear the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. The minister will remember the Prime Minister giving an ironclad guarantee in the run-up to the last election that money from the Telstra fund—the Natural Heritage Trust fund—would not be diverted to other purposes. Yet last week the minister asserted that $12 million out of the $18 million Commonwealth contribution to fixing the Hume Dam will, indeed, come out of the Natural Heritage Trust fund. Madam President, this is a massive breach of promise. It is a massive diversion of millions of dollars out of the Natural Heritage Trust fund.
—What is your question, Senator?

—I ask the minister: have further funds from the Natural Heritage Trust fund been diverted to repairing the Hume Dam via allocations to the states? If the states did the same thing as the Commonwealth, it could add up to $48 million being filched out of the Natural Heritage Trust fund.

—Senator Brown asked me a similar question last week. Following question time—and I have forgotten whether it was on Wednesday or Thursday—I gave a detailed response to Senator Brown provided to me by Minister Anderson. There is nothing more that I can add to that, except that I will refer the additional questions asked by Senator Brown in respect to the states to the minister and get him to reply.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Having confirmed that, in fact, the Prime Minister's promise has been breached and money is going to non-environmental purposes from this massive fund, I ask the minister: has up to $48 million actually been diverted from the Murray-Darling 2001 program—which is for environmental purposes, including the improvement of the health of key river systems, encouraging ecologically and economically sustainable land use, restoring riverbank land systems, wetlands and flood plains, or improving water quality—to the capital works on this dam which have nothing to do with the environment?
—I will refer those detailed questions to Minister Anderson and get Senator Brown a reply.

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Information: Ministers' Travel Costs

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Minchin, representing those elements of DoFA that he does. I refer to the government's decision to exempt certain information contained in the Kennedy report from release under the FOI Act. Can the minister confirm that the reasons cited in the section 26 statement for the exemption of certain material were: internal processes of government and the analysis of possible disciplinary offences; protecting the efficient conduct of the management of Commonwealth personnel; protecting the unreasonable disclosure of personal information about an individual; and legal professional privilege? Why then did the government exempt from release those aspects of the report that would have disclosed the prior knowledge of the Prime Minister's office of travel costs of ministers?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —There was a report in the Canberra Times this morning about the so-called Kennedy report and it suggested that regular management reports went to the Prime Minister's office detailing ministers' travel expenditure. That, of course, was not in fact the case. What went were reports to the Prime Minister's office to give an indication of the quantum of travel being undertaken by ministers and parliamentary secretaries, not details of individual transactions.

answer.para: Of course, this government has responded to those matters in a most comprehensive fashion. We have taken very active measures to reform the whole system of parliamentary entitlements which we inherited from the previous government, which had not taken this sort of action in the 13 years it had been in office. We have done so through a very open and transparent process, including at appropriate times the Remuneration Tribunal in our reforms. Of course, we have engaged in a very thorough and complete overhaul of travel and travel allowance entitlements. Certainly, any suggestion that the government avoided acting on the concerns expressed about the entitlement system are completely unfounded.

Turning to the Kennedy report, as Senator Ray knows, that does represent the findings of an internal inquiry within the Department of Finance and Administration. It was properly constituted under the Public Service Act to establish whether any officer of the former Department of Administrative Services failed to fulfil his or her duty in relation to the May 1998 tabling of travel information. It was not a review of the government's management of parliamentary entitlements and, as has been noted, appropriate sections of that report have already been released under freedom of information provisions. Further, I advise that it was not appropriate for privacy and legal reasons to release the full text of the report.

Further, the Department of Finance and Administration will be following its usual procedures to determine whether there has been any unauthorised disclosure of information in this case. I am not able to go into the details of the privacy and legal reasons why the full text of the report was not made available. If I am able to give Senator Ray any further information either privately or in here, I will do so.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst I appreciate the extent of Senator Minchin's reply, he did not go to the thrust of my question. I concur with him that not all elements of the Kennedy report should be released, nor should they have been released to me under FOI. But, comparing the now complete report with the deleted report, I am just asking why this piece of information was deleted when it did not meet the criteria under FOI for deletion; when it had some hint of political sensitivity, no irregularity—it is quite proper for a Prime Minister to know whether his ministers are abusing travel allowance. But why delete that particular section when it meets no criteria under the FOI Act or by the FOI officer? Why actually expunge it when other matters, I agree, should have been expunged?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The decision on the deletion was, of course, not mine, but I will have to take that question on notice and provide you with the information that you seek.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to a report in the CBD section of the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 May 1998, which states that the Australian Taxation Office is conducting a continuing investigation into the affairs of:

question.para: . . . one of the country's most recognisable faces, regarding a snortingly good profit earned on his rural interests.

Can the minister confirm public speculation that the person in question is none other than Mr P.J. Keating, the former Labor Prime Minister? As today's Sydney Morning Herald makes it clear that Mr Keating's true profit was many millions of dollars, what steps will the government take to ensure that all tax liability to the Commonwealth arising from the sale of Mr Keating's piggery interests has been made in full? Can the minister also inform the Senate of the status of the tax office's investigation?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. On consistent rulings that you have made, at least the first part of that question from Senator Abetz is clearly out of order.
—I agree.
—And Madam President—
—I need no further advice on the matter.
—Well, Madam President, a further point of order: with respect, I think the second part is out of order also.
—The second part is not; the first part is. I call Senator Hill.
—Yes, I saw this little piece about the `snortingly good profit' in the Sydney Morning Herald .

—Madam President, on a point of order: hasn't the Leader of the Government just immediately flouted your ruling by canvassing part of a question that was directed to him that you have ruled out of order? I would ask you to enforce the ruling that you have made, enforce the standing orders, and not allow the Leader of the Government to flout your rulings in this way.
—There is no suggestion he is flouting. He made an observation, on a part which is out of order. He will deal with the second part, which I will allow him to do.

—Perhaps Senator Faulkner knows more than I do because I cannot confirm that it is Mr Keating, but I do know that they apply a different standard to their own side. It is interesting that this little snippet at the trough refers to an issue over a windfall profit of $10.5 million. What we saw in the Sydney Morning Herald was a suggestion that Mr Keating had been paid $6 million, but that he had had a further interest that he had disposed of to the Indonesians a year later in March 1995 and then finally in 1996 got rid of the rest of his interest. Of course, none of this came out in the House of Representatives disclosure. That is a different issue.

answer.para: It is interesting that the third charge the Labor Party levels against Senator Parer is that he is wealthy. That is the basis for condemnation. Senator Carr gets to his feet every day and condemns Senator Parer for being wealthy, playing on the old politics of envy. Yet the former Prime Minister, the head of the Australian Labor Party, a multimillionaire, sells out his interest for millions of dollars to rich Indonesian businessmen, and that is an entirely different thing. Did we see Senator Carr come in here and condemn the leadership of the ALP for being wealthy? No, of course, that is entirely different. Did he condemn them for the circumstances of their being wealthy? No, entirely. I do not know whether it is referring to Mr Keating, but the Sydney Morning Herald suggests that—
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Carr.
—After the final settlement in 1996 of the sale of his piggery interest, he was able to settle on his $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra, Senator Carr—the leader of the battlers' party.
—What about Senator Parer?
—Senator Carr.

—It was a $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra, and then he bought Mr Laws' riverfront house, a weekender, for another $1 million. It was a good deal for Mr Keating certainly, a very wealthy leader of the ALP. But that is not to be condemned by the Australian Labor Party because that does not suit their political interest. But because Senator Parer worked hard in his business life and made a dollar, for that, he should be condemned and he should be dragged through the political mire because he made a bit of money in the past. What hypocrisy! What double standards! We see them yet again.
—My question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security.
—Did you have a lemon juice for lunch?
—You had eight cream buns, we know that.
—It was a moderate day: she had only eight cream buns; she usually has about a dozen.
—I know it has been a long session, but question time is an important part of the day. Senator Collins, start again, please.

—It has, indeed, been a long session. Minister, is it a fact that the government's youth allowance policies are designed to encourage 18- to 20-year-olds to stay at home? Can the minister confirm, though, that, at the same time, Centrelink is currently advising clients receiving the disability support pension that 16-year-old children are no longer considered dependent for the purposes of the income test and is cutting their pensions accordingly? Can the minister confirm that the Centrelink policy unit has confirmed that this anomaly exists? What action does the government intend to take to correct this problem?
—The answer to the first part of Senator Collins's question is no. As to the second part of her question, I will get advice from Centrelink and get back to her.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In seeking that information, I draw the minister's attention, as Minister for Social Security, to a Hampton Park Centrelink client who received advice in late June that his disability support pension had been cut from $140.80 per fortnight to $134.50 because his 16-year-old daughter, who is in year 11, is now receiving youth allowance, instead of Austudy, and is no longer considered depend ent for the purposes of the client income test. Can the minister confirm that clients contacting Centrelink are being advised that the Centrelink Policy Unit is considering measures to correct this absurd situation, and they are also being advised that the only way to rectify the situation at the moment is to leave their family?

—Of course the government is not prepared to endorse any suggestion that young people should be persuaded to leave their family. The youth allowance policy, which is very family oriented, is not intended to achieve that. Sadly, over the last few weeks the behaviour of opposition members, both in this chamber and in the other chamber, and of the Democrats' spokesman has led me to be very careful about what is stated by them to be the truth. We saw only the other day Senator Carr come in here and tell me that somebody was going to have all their payments cut off and in fact they are not. Senator Stott Despoja has told us how young people are going to breached if they do not return their forms. That is not true again. Senator Collins, as I said to you, I am very happy to look to see whether there is any anomaly in the system, but it sounds rather strange and I must investigate it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be arriving in Jakarta today for a series of meetings with President Habibie, Foreign Minister Ali Alatas and Armed Forces Commander, General Wiranto. Does the foreign minister intend to discuss human rights in these talks? Will the minister specifically raise the role of ABRI in the death of six demonstrators and the wounding of 140 others in West Papua yesterday—people who had done no more than raise a flag? Finally, during these talks, will the minister advocate free and fair votes of self-determination in West Papua and East Timor or does the government believe that in Indonesia, as in Australia, the central government should determine the rights of indigenous peoples with no reference to the peoples themselves?

—Mr Downer will be conveying some key messages of Australian support for Indonesia. As we have discussed in this place before, Indonesia is going through a difficult phase of political and economic change. It has been the attitude of the Australian government that Australia should be supportive of Indonesia during this difficult process of change and that we should demonstrate that we are in it for the long haul with our near neighbour.

answer.para: Mr Downer will indicate that Australia will work with the Indonesian government and encourage it to implement the pressing political and economic reforms that Indonesia is now committed to implement. He will indicate that we believe that this is not only in the interests of stability within the region but also clearly consistent with the wishes of the Indonesian people themselves.

I understand that Mr Downer will meet President Habibie and Foreign Minister Alatas. Although the emphasis of his visit is very much directed towards the economic side of the Indonesian challenge, I have little doubt that he will raise issues of human rights, which we believe are also important to build a confident, stable and democratic Indonesia in the future.

The events of the very recent times in Irian Jaya are distressing. I am aware of reports of the shooting incidents and, sadly, of the deaths of some protesters, and I think at least one ABRI member. I am also aware of the role that the Indonesian Commission on Human Rights has been playing in investigating—this is referring to the previous demonstration and violence, but I am sure it will continue in more recent instances—allegations of violations of authorities in the region.

We would argue that, modest though it might be, that is a good sign. Everything that President Habibie has said to date does appear to indicate that he is wanting to see Indonesia get through this difficult period of transition in a way that does not suppress human rights, as has perhaps occurred in the past, that does lead to a more open society, that does lead to a more democratic society. We do not under estimate the stresses that will be involved during that process of political change.

Whilst obviously the incident in Irian Jaya is distressing, I suppose it would be a little too much to expect that Indonesia will be able to go through such a dramatic period of change without some incidents of violence of this kind. We would certainly urge both sides of these political disputes to restrain from violence, to seek within the spirit of a more democratic Indonesia to resolve their differences through peaceful means. I think that that is the best way in which we can, as I said, contribute to what is a very dramatic process of change occurring within our near neighbour. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that encouraging answer, particularly his reference to the Indonesian Commission on Human Rights. Could he answer part three of my question, which was, in essence: will Australia, in our usual quiet and restrained way, be telling the Indonesian government that we would be in favour of self-determination for any of the peoples of Indonesia?

—The honourable senator knows that we believe Irian Jaya to be part of Indonesia. We are certainly not going to go out and promote an independent stand. Not only is it not our business, but it will lead to internal instability and more violence of the type that Senator Bourne is seeking to avoid. If there are political differences as to the future of Indonesia and the component parts of the state of Indonesia, we want to see those resolved peacefully from within. Our emphasis should be on encouraging that peaceful dialogue and the settling of political problems in a way that is more akin to that accepted in democratic nations such as ours. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday, during question time, Senator Brown took a point of order on the actions of an attendant in the press gallery. Seating in the press gallery of the Senate is reserved for members of the federal parliamentary press gallery. The attendant had noticed that a person in the gallery did not have an appropriate press gallery pass. On approaching the person, the attendant also advised him and his companion of the dress standards applying in the gallery. The two people readily agreed to move to the public gallery. Members of the press gallery are required to comply with a set of guidelines governing their conduct in Parliament House. Among other things, the guidelines require that members of the gallery, when in the press gallery of the Senate or the House of Representatives, should maintain the standards of dress adopted by the majority of senators and members when attending in the chambers. With the concurrence of senators, I incorporate in Hansard a copy of the guidelines relating to the press gallery, for the information of senators.

speech.para: CONDITIONS TO BE OBSERVED BY MEMBERS OF THE FEDERAL PARLIAMENTARY PRESS GALLERY AND REPRESENTATIVES OF OTHER MEDIA ORGANISATIONS ADMITTED TO PARLIAMENT HOUSE

The Presiding Officers have determined that the following conditions shall be observed by members of the Federal Parliamentary Press Gallery in Parliament House and representatives of other media organisations admitted to Parliament House.
As a general rule members of the Gallery wishing to speak with a senator or member in Parliament House should make an appointment by telephone.

Members of the Gallery may not enter the Lobbies of the Senate or the House of Representatives and should not linger in the corridors in the vicinity of the Cabinet Room or Party Rooms. During Cabinet or Party meetings, this prohibition is absolute. In these areas, members of the Gallery may not seek to engage senators or members in conversation.
Members of the Gallery are not permitted to enter the Members' Dining Room or Members' Bar.

In addition to studios and press conference rooms, media photographers and television crews may film on invitation in private rooms, committee rooms and at official functions elsewhere in the building. Similar conditions apply to tape recordings by radio journalists. Filming or tape recording in other circumstances throughout the building and its courtyards is prohibited without the specific approval of the President and/or the Speaker.

Journalists and camera crews must not stand at the entrances to Parliament House so as to impede the access of senators, members or others to the building. They should avoid using the areas in the immediate vicinity of the entrances for the purposes of interviewing senators, members or other persons. In any event, journalists and camera crews must conform with the directions of attendants or Australian Protective Service officers at the entrances.

Members of the Gallery when in the Press Gallery of the Senate or the House of Representatives, should maintain the standards of dress adopted by the majority of senators and members when attending in the Chambers.

Members of the Gallery sponsoring admission of visitors into Parliament House are responsible for those visitors until they leave the building. Where those visitors are representatives of media organisations, the member is responsible for advising the visitors of these conditions.
Parliamentary officers administer these conditions with understanding and flexibility but can do so only with the co-operation of members of the Gallery.
Abuse of these conditions by members of the Gallery may result in the rights of access to Parliament House of an individual or organisation being restricted.
(Agreed to by the Presiding Officers in 1989).
