What might be able to be considered, were this matter to be somehow deferred and redrafted, is a provision for this matter to be reviewed. A simple review provision in the legislation might require that the minister report to the parliament and that powers which he was exercising were exercised as regulations which might then be disallowable. I am only speaking off the top of my head, because, as I say, we have not had time to give any great consideration to the proposition which you now put. The situation might then be that somehow the model which comes into being, if it does not receive total industry support, could be further reviewed by the parliament. That could simply be a mechanism to refer the matter to a committee for report to the Senate or it could be some other mechanism. I am really in your hands, as it were, Senator Margetts, as to what alternatives might be put forward in relation to this proposition. But to simply say that this provision not be given effect without this complicated procedure that you propose would pose more problems than it would solve.

As I intimated earlier, it seems to me that what can occur in relation to the Western Australian Farmers Federation position, which I accept you are pursuing as strongly as you can, is that that matter can continue to be pursued within the Grains Council as a first step. If there is an acceptance within the Grains Council, as I would hope there is, that it is desirable for there to be a united position of the grower organisations around Australia rather than, effectively, a split position on the appropriate model for the Australian Wheat Board, the Grains Council would use all of its powers to achieve that end and would make recommendations to Minister Anderson in relation to achieving a position which had the united support of growers around this country as their interests are reflected in the organisa tions which are affiliates of the Grains Council.

I would suggest that it ought to go without saying that Minister Anderson ought not take any actions in relation to the setting of provisions in the memorandum and articles of association which do not have the united support of growers through the Grains Council. The first thing that ought to be said is that, if there are any questions as to adequate representation or reflection of the views of the Grains Council, those questions ought to be resolved and, secondly, the minister ought to refrain from taking initiatives in relation to the memorandum and articles to resolve matters in the absence of agreement. That might prolong matters somewhat but, after all, it is in the interests of growers as well as the government that this process be resolved amicably. The minister should be able to use his good offices to persuade the grower organisations that it is possible, indeed desirable, for their position to be a united one and that he would be in a very difficult position trying to implement something which had the united opposition of grower organisations around this country.

Senator Margetts, I am not sure what your views are on how we should approach your proposition and achieve an outcome which might find acceptance. I do think it is fair to say that, in its current form, the amendments will not be supported by the opposition. I do not rule out support for an alternative position, but perhaps you might like to consider, if the Senate is prepared to, deferring consideration of this matter. It seems to me that it is unlikely that we will conclude the committee stage of this bill this evening. Perhaps we could revisit this tomorrow in some amended form if that is your wish rather than your amendments, I suspect, going down on the basis of the words of the legislation, unless the government is intent on supporting this proposition. I think not, but that may be the case. It would be interesting to get the views of Senator Margetts on that proposition before we proceed further.

talk.start.para: —I will address some of the issues briefly before I specifically address the propo sition that has been put forward by Senator O'Brien. Obviously, as the Western Australian Farmers Federation are the ones who are keen to put forward a consideration of their model, it is unlikely that they would be deliberately blocking consideration of the model. They might be choosy about what is an independent body, but I do not think that is unreasonable. They are still talking enough between them to work out that there is a body that they would be able to utilise. If this is in legislation, I think it is everybody's interests. It is probably less likely to be the Western Australian Farmers Federation than anybody else that would not be able to come to an agreement about what might be a good entity to be able to put forward this model.

speech.para: They do not get power of veto over the report. They do not have to keep doing the report until they get something that everybody is happy with, because that is not likely to happen. I think, for this level of frustration, they are saying that they want somebody—not just themselves—to look into this proposal. They would like to make sure that the person or group or entity that is looking into that proposal could be agreed on as an entity that is acceptable to the members of the Grains Council of Australia. I do not think that is an odd thing for them to ask.

If it is a matter of some wording changes that would satisfy everybody, I am absolutely certain that the Western Australian Farmers Federation would be very happy for me to move that consideration of Greens (WA) amendments (3) and (4) be deferred until later on in the debate. If there is a chance that a change of wording will satisfy the concerns of the ALP and, hopefully, gain support from the Senate, I would be happy to do so. Therefore, I move:
That further consideration of the amendments be postponed.
Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —Are we not going to have a chance to talk about the situation? Do you not want a chance for people to talk about it further? This is ridiculous.
—Order! I put the motion, Senator Margetts, and I called the noes. The question now is that amendments (3) and (4) moved by Senator Margetts be agreed to.

—Senator O'Brien has outlined the position of the opposition. I am not in any way being critical of Senator Margetts. She and the Greens were placed in the same position that all of us were—that is, having to address these issues in a very short space of time—but we do not see that the solution here is to just drop the model that is in the legislation which has been given substantial support by the industry and move what would be a number of steps backward.

speech.para: As I said in my earlier remarks both in the debate on the cut-off motion and in the debate on the second reading, the problem that the Senate has is that the industry is split. The majority of the peak bodies—the state grower organisations and the Grains Council—have over a long time developed a particular model, and they support that model, with reservations and with anticipated warts.

The Western Australian Farmers Federation does not support that model. We have a great deal of sympathy for the position of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. We have said that all the way through the debate. Our sympathy with their position is that they are representative of a substantial number of grain growers, particularly from the export side of the industry. Our concern all along has been to try to find a way in which they were not, in the end, bludgeoned into submission, into accepting or having the industry model forced on them, without giving them ample opportunity to try to either convince the other states of their changes, develop a proposal or in the end come to agree with it.

Unfortunately, the option that is now being put up by Senator Margetts, whilst it is intended to try to find some more breathing space, some more time for the industry parties to go away and work out a solution, does not really take it any further. If anything, what it seems to me to do is to ensure that this matter will still be hanging around this parliament come next year. The proposal is not, for instance, one that would be dealt with in a couple of weeks. It seeks to establish an independent body. It would take some time for the minister to get agreement from all of the state associations as to who the independent body would be.

I said flippantly across the chamber a moment ago to Senator Ferguson and Senator Crane that Paul Houlihan and Jamie Ferguson have probably got nothing to do at the moment and maybe they could get the consultancy to investigate this matter, having failed so dismally in their efforts on the waterfront. I am not sure that even they would be acceptable to all the various bodies within the industry, but it is a real problem. If the industry organisations in Western Australia and in the eastern states are still having trouble reaching unanimity on what is on the table and what has been developed over a period of time within the framework of the Grains Council, how are you going to get them to agree on an independent body that is acceptable to all the state affiliates?

I turn to the different models for the constitutions of nominated companies. It has been said in the other place and in here that the opposition has some attraction to the cooperative model. But at the end of the day it is not the Labor Party's model, it is not the Liberal Party's model or the National Party's model. This has to be a corporate structure or a cooperative structure to which the growers themselves are committed, not one that is simply based upon partisan politics. That has been our position ever since we started the process of restructuring and reform over 10 years ago. The danger is that, in agreeing to this process, we will end up, if anything, maybe driving the organisations further apart.

At the moment we have the Grains Council, the New South Wales Farmers Association, the Queensland cane growers and the Victorians and the South Australians in the cart supporting one industry model, albeit with different degrees of enthusiasm, but that is what they are supporting. They have their reservations; they have all put their caveats on it if it does not work, but that is where they are at. As I said earlier, the Western Australian Farmers Federation are in a different position. They are not in the cart. The danger is that, if you adopt this proposal put up by the Greens, the wheels will fall off the cart and they will all go back to square one. The New South Wales Farmers Association might decide to develop their own model. The Queensland grain growers might like to put together some other model.

talk.start.para: —That's a good idea.

—The problem with that is that you are building in delay and delay and delay that will not be in the interests of the industry. There are time lines that have to be considered. That, to me, is a recipe for more chaos. At the moment, notwithstanding the difficulties that exist with the groups reaching agreement, the last thing we want to be doing as a Senate is—
—Is wasting time.

—No, is creating the potential for everybody to say, `Let's go back to square one and start again.' That is why we cannot support the proposal. It does not mean that this proposal may not have some merit and may not be dealt with in another way. For instance, as has been said, the minister can have a look at the proposal, and I urge him to do so because it seems that, unfortunately, the minister has put up the shutters on this issue some time ago, and maybe that is why we are in the position we are in today.

speech.para: Secondly, it is something that may well be able to be looked at within the structure of the memorandum and articles of association of the companies. We are not charged with the responsibility for drafting that. The minister is ultimately in the position to approve that. It has been indicated, as I understand it, by the Western Australian Farmers Federation representatives that that was another option for them—to look at accepting the current corporate grower model, notwithstanding that they do not like it, and then to try to deal with their particular concerns, such as ensuring continuity of grower control and so on within the company structures as that would be outlined in the constitution and in the memorandum and articles of association.

I think it is important to put that on the record so it is clearly understood. I know that people from the various organisations have been listening to this debate because the phone calls are continually coming in—and I am not sure what the poll is at the moment. But that is the position of the opposition on these amendments.

talk.start.para: —Actually, two separate positions have been given by the opposition. I clearly responded earlier by giving a motion in response to Senator O'Brien suggesting that there might be a problem with the form of wording. That, of course, is the reason why I suggested and put a motion that these particular amendments be deferred. I cannot remember the last time when I have been present in the committee stage where that motion has been denied.

speech.para: I just wonder whether there really is agreement among opposition senators. If what we potentially have is the chance of there being a form of wording that the Senate might accept, then I can talk on this amendment for as long as possible. I can speak in relation to Senator Woodley's amendments, Senator Murray's amendments and, once again, Senator Woodley's amendment. That gives us a chance to talk through some of the issues.

Basic democracy would suggest that, if there is the potential to work through a form of wording that would be acceptable, it would be smarter for us to do that now than to vote in or out elements of the legislation and later on have to argue about it. If there is the potential for dealing with that, it is unlikely that before 7.30 p.m. we are going to be able to deal with the five amendments we are dealing with or, altogether, the six. Therefore, to be able to deal with that, it would make sense simply to defer the vote.

I am not sure whether is was inexperience or not from the parliamentary secretary or the advisers as to why that course would not be considered acceptable. But I just want to point out that, if we are to get through this debate reasonably, it is not unreasonable to suggest that the Senate have the opportunity to look at those issues where there might be the potential for an agreement that is acceptable to the majority of the Senate.

To deny the ability of the Senate to look at those issues and perhaps work out acceptable forms of wording does not make sense. We are not going to solve anything for the indus try—or for anyone, for that matter. Therefore I ask that the minister reconsider the leave that I sought, and perhaps I would ask it again: I again seek leave to defer consideration of Greens (WA) amendments 3 and 4. They can then be put again after we have considered Democrats 1, Democrats 1 and 2, Democrats 2 and government 1 to 3. I think it would be a miracle if we were to do all of this before 7.30 p.m. I do not think what I am suggesting is unreasonable. So I do seek again leave to defer Greens (WA) amendments 3 and 4.

talk.start.para: —I would just indicate that, while I am not sure that a form of words will solve the problems that they have, I think it is a fairly reasonable request that Senator Margetts is putting. But I do not know what the Labor Party is doing, as I received two signals, I thought. There would not be much point in pressing this if the Labor Party does not agree to defer it as well.

speech.para: But it is only a deferral that I would support, because I think that is a reasonable suggestion. It does not seem to me that we are going to destroy the Australian wheat industry or send people off the planet by simply deferring for, I suppose, 20 minutes—because I am sure that we will not get to the end of this debate tonight—and giving Senator Margetts a chance at least to talk to those of the Labor Party, because they seem to be the ones who were raising the possibility of a new form of words. We need to know what they are saying; otherwise what I am saying does not have any relevance.

talk.start.para: —I am persuaded by the subsequent contributions of Senator Margetts and Senator Woodley. The position is that really we are not attracted to the amendments. At the time I was speaking, I actually had consideration of the fact that we might be able to finish the entire debate by 7.30 p.m. But that looks unlikely now.

speech.para: I am very sceptical of a form of words being able to be created, but I take the point that it is worth a try. It will not ultimately alter the outcome if we do not reach an agreement. So I am happy on that basis to indicate that we would support a deferral.

talk.start.para: —Senator Margetts, would you put the motion that those two amendments be deferred?
—I move:

speech.para: That further consideration of the amendments be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —We move on to Democrat amendment No. 1 on sheet 1077.
—I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 7, page 4 (after line 8), at the end of the clause, add:

(5) Notwithstanding any other provision in any other act, a B Class share which is taken to be issued to a person under subsection (1) is, for the purpose of establishing that person's liability for taxation, deemed to be an active asset for the purposes of Division 17A and 17B of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .
Note: For the meaning of active asset , see subsections 160ZZPL(3), (4), (5) and (6) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .

Again let me point out that with this amendment we are seeking something that, as far as I understand, all the peak bodies—and this is the one point of agreement—actually agree to, including the Western Australian Farmers Federation, and that I imagine most wheat farmers themselves would also agree to.

Certainly this is one of the issues that was raised in many of the faxes and communications that I have had. The reason for their doing this is that there is a question of equity and fairness here. I have tried to read the submission from the tax department and I have read the evidence from different sides of this debate, and I hear what is being said. Nevertheless, as I understand it, in converting WIF equity into shares of the new instrument, a compulsion is involved.

It seems to me that if there was an arrangement for tax relief under the old Wheat Industry Fund, then a similar arrangement ought to accrue to the new compulsory transfer. I cannot see why the government, the Taxation Office and everyone cannot understand the fairness in that. But I am prepared to listen again to the debate on this.

We are proposing something that is equitable and fair and that is supported by all of the industry bodies—and, I would imagine, by all of the individual wheat farmers, although I cannot give you a guarantee on that. The only group that I am not sure of is the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia. But, as I understood it, they wanted to retain the sunset clause. Perhaps they would also agree with the proposition on the taxation issue. I wait with interest to hear other contributions.

talk.start.para: —When I am considering this amendment, it strikes me as a basic issue of equity that if a person changes their structure in such a way as to enrich themselves, then their taxation status could be altered because the Taxation Office could take a particular view and take their cut. However, this is an instance where the taxation regime under which these farmers operate is being affected by the parliament. It is being affected by the legislature. It is not as a result of the personal action of the farmers. The legislature is determining how the farmers' shares will be rearranged and adjusted.

speech.para: It seems to me entirely inappropriate therefore to put those farmers at any taxation risk for an event which does not alter the essential nature of the asset that they hold. It is not something they have sold, transferred or moved; it is something that remains in their hands. Yet it seems to me that they will be potentially at risk of being penalised by the tax office for a change that results as a consequence of the bill. That is one of the essential issues of equity concerning me. I would be very interested to hear the response of those with responsibility for carriage of this bill in that regard.

talk.start.para: —I indicated in my contribution on the second reading of this bill that the opposition will not be supporting this amendment, and I detailed the breakdown of the value of the WIF funds and earnings once they are con verted into B class shares. Contained within that we have the WIF contributions and a value to reflect the depreciated value of those contributions, which have not been taxed and will be available tax free. This amendment is proposing that a component, which in total terms is worth $221 million, be treated in some cases as an active asset even though it has been converted to a shareholding.

speech.para: The first proposition that the opposition looked at in approaching this matter was: has there been unfair treatment of the growers in relation to their WIF funds? If it could be said that somehow they had lost the value of that money and they had already paid tax on that money, we might take a different view of this amendment. However, it is clear from the evidence which has been given to the committee by the Australian Taxation Office—I do not think there is any evidence to contradict this—that the WIF funds have not been taxed. That is, the contributions made by growers to the WIF have not been taxed. Tax has not been paid on the contributions. It has been either a deduction or not declared as income.

Secondly—and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Troeth) made this clear in her speech on the second reading—a value to reflect a depreciation of those funds will be given upon conversion to shareholding, and that value will also not be taxable. So we have the real value of the WIF funds, arguably, being reflected as the cost of the shares and being tax free at the point where the shares are redeemed. In other words, there has been no loss by virtue of a compulsory contribution. The full value of the contributions together with the notional cost of living earnings of those contributions are tax free—no loss because of the compulsory contribution.

If the growers decide to take their WIF funds before conversion to shares—and that is available—then they will be treated as active assets. It would then be a matter of chance, frankly. The reality is that I think most growers would take advantage of the conversion of those WIF funds into shares because, if they do that, they also get the potential value in the shares of the assets, the goodwill and the single desk which would reside in the company. They are able to recover that value upon sale of the B class shares. Now that proportion, which exceeds the indexed value of their contribution, will be taxable. We do not think that is an unfair proposition.

In terms of the question of whether we ought to support this because the majority of organisations who have lobbied us are seeking this, I am reminded of a saying from a good friend of mine—that is, in the race of life always back self-interest; it is always trying. In this case there is no question that the grower organisations are doing what their constituent members would expect them to do in seeking to get the best possible deal. However, in acceding to the proposition as far as we have, we do not think they have an unfair deal now, and we think it would be unfair to the community to give them what they ask for.

talk.start.para: —The government will not be accepting this amendment. Effectively, wheat growers would receive a double deduction for their contributions. They have not paid any tax since 1989. They will not pay tax when the units are converted to shares, and they will not pay any tax until the shares are sold at some time in the future. To put through an amendment like this would not be fair to every other person in the Australian community who has to abide by the rules of taxation and make a fair contribution. The taxation arrangements are already generous, fair and equitable, and we do not see any reason to extend any further concessions.

speech.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Serious allegations raised in the Sydney Morning Herald today, and aired in the Senate today, concerning business transactions of the former Labor leader, Mr Keating, whilst Prime Minister need to be answered. It was therefore devastatingly disappointing for the Australian people to learn on the news bulletins this evening that the former Labor leader had no comment to make about these serious allegations. It must also be disappointing for Mr Beazley and other Labor luminaries who sat around Mr Keating's Labor cabinet table.

speech.para: The allegations that surfaced today are not completely new. Honourable senators would recall that these issues were raised and pursued by former distinguished Senator Michael Baume. He raised them quite properly and quite relentlessly. Given those allegations, one must ask the question: did Mr Beazley ask his then Labor leader whether there was any substance to the allegations? If he did ask the question, it raises the further question: was Mr Beazley the recipient of another Keating lie? Or was Mr Beazley told, and did Mr Beazley do nothing about it, making him, as the then Labor finance minister, potentially complicit in the cover-up?

The further alternative is that Mr Beazley may well have been too weak to ask the question. Mr Beazley has form for being unable to ask himself and Labor the tough questions in the area of policy, so we may need to give Mr Beazley the benefit of the doubt on this. But failure to ask the question would just add further to the mounting perception in the community that Mr Beazley is a weak leader. He will not confront the tough issues.

The reason that this issue has continually been on the public agenda is that Labor has this reputation of putting trade union officials, such as Mr Keating, into parliament and turning out millionaires—a metamorphosis that cannot have been achieved no matter how far and wide the parliamentary salary was spun. The thread used to spin this financial cocoon to turn this poor trade union official into a multimillionaire during his parliamentary life was not the thread made of parliamentary salaries. The thread clearly has an origin from elsewhere. We now know it hailed from Indonesia. The threads are coming together and are now weaving a tapestry revealing deception and potential abuse of office.

Why does a business figure, especially from overseas, not having had any major dealings in Australia before, seek to relieve a Labor Prime Minister of a $13 million debt and pay not only for the debt but also an extra $6 million for the privilege of so relieving him of that debt? It stretches credulity beyond even Labor's low standards to expect the Australian people to believe that this was an arms-length, above the board deal. It raises, indeed demands, the question: what else was involved in the deal? What was the true consideration that passed between Mr Keating and the foreigner? Labor seems to have this fatal attraction for funny money deals. Remember the Khemlani loan scandal of the 1970s? The big difference in this case is that Mr Keating's funny money deal was solely for his own personal benefit.

If it was all above board, why would the former Labor leader declare only 10 per cent of the gain if there was nothing to hide? It really is a pity the Labor leader could not use his now legendary economic wizardry of turning a $13 million debt into a $6 million profit for the benefit of the Australian people. If making money is that easy, why couldn't he have turned the legacy of Labor's $80 billion federal government debt that he left the Australian people into a $36 billion government surplus? Indeed, One Nation could well be interested in the Labor leader's expertise, because it seems he made money quicker than it could be printed.

These revelations today demand an answer from Labor's dynamo of the 1980s and 1990s. To say, as he was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today, that, `My private business affairs are private to me,' is acceptable if this happened before or after his political life. But it is totally unacceptable to say, `They are my private business affairs and they are private to me,' when they occurred during his occupation of the Lodge.
Issues raised are plentiful. This morning, Mr Alan Jones spoke with one of the investigative journalists. I will read from part of the transcript of that interview. Mr Jones asked:

How does someone with an investment, as I understand Mr Keating's was, of $430,000 return, when it's $13 million in debt, at least $600,000 and the argument that he got some millions over and above that in separate payments?
Answer: It's the question we asked many people throughout our inquiries and I guess I'm still waiting for an answer on them.
That, of course, all happened while Mr Keating was the Labor Prime Minister. Another question asked was:

Do you have evidence that $6 million or a figure of that amount was transferred from Mr Soeryadjaya's company trust to a trust account that had held Mr Keating's and Mr Constantinidis' piggery's interests?
Answer: Yes, yes, we did.
Question: What amount?
Answer: Well, the amount that Mr Soeryadjaya's company initially put in was definitely over $6 million, there's no question about that.
Question: And you have evidence that that was transferred from Mr Soeryadjaya's company trust to a trust account that held the piggery interests of Mr Keating and Mr Constantinidis?

Answer: That's right, that's right, and we have that document and I spoke to, you know, because you can never fully trust documents, but I did speak to people that confirm that over $6 mil lion had gone into the trust account of the piggeries.

Of course, it is now on the public record that Mr Keating's business partner, Mr Constantinidis, and Mr Keating are no longer on speaking terms. Their only communication is now through solicitors' letters.

The issues that I have raised this evening are issues of great moment for Australia. It is the first time that I can recall in Australia's history that such a terrible shadow has been cast over the person who has held the very top office of this country. Therefore, my submission to the Senate tonight is that the allegations posed, the questions raised, need to be answered by the former Labor leader. Further, Mr Beazley, Senator Faulkner, Senator Ray and the others who have so unsuccessfully sought to pursue current ministers need to come clean and tell the Australian people what they know about these sordid dealings. Their failure to respond will speak volumes, especially in the weeks to come.

talk.start.para: —The so-called unsuccessful pursuit of ministers in the Howard government has already led to the scalps of seven frontbenchers since the election in March 1996. A number of senior staff have also resigned.

speech.para: It is the staff issue that I want to speak about tonight. It took three hours for the Senator Parer/Mr Baudino camp to cobble together a pathetically weak explanation as to why one of Senator Parer's staff purchased Telstra shares in defiance of the prohibition by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Senator Alston's media spinners were immediately in the press gallery, claiming that we in the Labor Party had done great wrong to Mr Baudino. Since then, they have retired hurt.

However, we do now know what Senator Parer's media spin is, and it is as I am about to outline. Senator Parer says that he told his staff of the Prime Minister's prohibition; that is possibly true. Senator Parer apparently demands from his staff an annual declaration of pecuniary interests. That happened in the previous government; that is possibly true also. Mr Baudino's broker claims that Mr Baudino did not purchase shares in his own name. So what? Finally come the admissions from the media spinners. The shares were bought in Mr Baudino's name but he did not know about it. It is claimed that Mr Baudino had some sort of blind trust arrangements with his wife.

The facts are these: the shares were listed on the Coopers and Lybrand Telstra Corporation share register in the name of Robert Laurence Baudino on 25 November 1997, not in the name of a trust. Two days later, on 27 November 1997, they were transferred to the joint names of Robert Laurence Baudino and Olive Merle Baudino. There is no mention of a trust on the Telstra share register. The shares are still listed in the joint names of Robert Laurence Baudino and Olive Merle Baudino as of today, 8 July 1998. On 27 November 1997, Olive Merle Baudino acquired an additional 5,600 units in her own name and separate from the parcel referred to above. As of today, 8 July 1998, she still holds these shares.

We are asked to accept that Mr Baudino never knew he owned these Telstra shares. How is that possible? The opposition could perhaps be provided with some supportive evidence. Perhaps we could have a copy of the applications for Telstra shares in the initial float and any applications in his name or her name, joint names or trust names. Perhaps we could have copies of the cheques that formed part of those applications in order to ascertain whose signatures are on the cheques or cheque, the name of the account upon which the cheque was drawn and who the signatories are to that account or those accounts.

If Mr Baudino does have an arrangement with his accountant in the form of a blind trust, we ask: is it done under a power of attorney? If so, does a copy of the power of attorney exist? Can the Senate be provided with a copy of the power of attorney? If not, how is it possible for his accountant to apply in somebody else's name for shares in Telstra—or in any other company, for that matter—without a power of attorney? Isn't an application in somebody else's name, without their knowledge, tantamount to fraud in the absence of a power of attorney to authorise that signature on the application?

We want to know if, since the time of the Telstra share purchase, Mr Baudino has received an issuer-sponsored statement advising him of the number of instalment receipts issued; in other words, his shareholding. We would like to know the reference number, if it exists. Perhaps we could be informed whether Mr Baudino received advice from time to time of any movement in his shareholding account. Perhaps we can be informed whether he received his dividend advice statement for the Telstra dividend of 7c per share paid on 31 March this year. That advice was, as I understand it, received by all shareholders in early April this year. We want to know if Mr Baudino received it.

Mr Baudino has not been available to the press this afternoon. In Mr Baudino we have a person who is well known for trawling the galleries; he is a particularly voluble and dissembling individual. But he has suddenly pulled down the cone of silence. Mr Baudino is absolutely nowhere to be seen. Today he left the media-spinning job, for the first time ever, to Senator Parer's very unenthusiastic senior adviser. When that senior adviser is challenged for details about this particular issue, that senior adviser has a stock standard response which is, we believe, very noteworthy for its lack of conviction. The stock standard response in relation to these issues is: `That's what Bob Baudino has told us.' Bob Baudino seems to have learned an awful lot from Senator Parer about how to deal with these sorts of issues.

talk.start.para: —He did a bundle on Rundle shares last time.

—He certainly did, Senator Ray. As you would know, a search of Hansard for Mr Baudino's name would show this particular individual has quite a chequered history, going back to the time of the old Government Information Unit during the life of the Fraser government.

speech.para: I want to raise one other important issue again, and that is this: do not forget that Senator Hill came into this chamber after question time yesterday and made a brief statement in response to a question asked by Senator Ray on Monday this week. I will quote part of his statement. He said:
Other ministers and parliamentary secretaries and their staff were advised not to buy shares for 90 days after the first trade.

It sounds pretty straightforward, doesn't it? But what we did not get from Senator Hill were the details for both cabinet and non-cabinet ministers, staff, family members, trustees and anyone else mentioned in the actual letter that was sent by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. Sure, we got some information, in a qualified way, but the government still has not had the guts to table the letter, the advice, that was given to cabinet and non-cabinet ministers and parliamentary secretaries. You have got to ask why. I suspect the government knows that Senator Parer—with his purchase of shares through IMPL—and now Mr Baudino have been caught red-handed in yet another breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines. This is yet another clear indication that in both cases they are guilty of seriously failing to live up to any level of proper accountability to parliamentary standards or proper public standards. They stand exposed and condemned. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak once again about the issues of immigration, multiculturalism and population policy in Australia. I do so having noted the efforts of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, today in finally looking to promote and reinforce some of the positives of the immigration program in Australia and some of the benefits of multiculturalism. I congratulate him on that. I hope that a defence of multiculturalism by the government is forthcoming in an even more effusive way in the future. I think that, as part of that, it is good to highlight in public debate the benefits of multiculturalism and the economic benefits of immigration. As part of that, it is, of course, crucial to ensure that adequate assistance and support is provided to migrants—people who have legitimately been accepted into this country—to ensure that they are fully able to participate in the economy and in the society that they have chosen to live in and that we have agreed to allow them to live in.

speech.para: In those circumstances it is important to look at the adequacy of funding—and the operation and ties that are attached to migrant settlement services—to organisations that work with people who are newly arrived to ensure that they can fully participate in Australian society. I call on the government to re-examine the adequacy of their funding and the nature of its assistance in those areas.

I would like, once again, to look at the issue of population policy in particular. There has been a lot of talk in recent times about population levels, immigration numbers, et cetera, and the environmental carrying capacity of the continent. Certainly, one of the justifications used by the One Nation Party in the zero net migration component of its immigration policy was the environmental aspect of having a sustainable population. That is an issue that the Democrats have long spoken about and for a long time have called for greater attention to be paid to it. Inasmuch as that issue is being acknowledged by others, that is something to welcome.

Of course, the many discriminatory aspects of the One Nation policy are not to be welcomed. The attacks on multiculturalism and the almost inevitable loss in employment that would arise from the negative approach of One Nation's policy are something that, naturally, the Democrats are totally opposed to. While people such as Robyn Spencer, in her previous guise with Australians Against Further Immigration and their promotion of a similarly discriminatory policy, have many times in the past talked about the ethnic mix of immigration and the need to avoid Asianisation of Australia, et cetera, organisations such as the Democrats, the Australian Conservation Foundation and Australians for an Ecologically Sustainable Population have all looked simply at the issue of total numbers, irrespective of whether they are native born or have their ethnic origin somewhere else.

One Nation—and others, unfortunately—has linked immigration numbers with unemploy ment and tried to perpetuate the myth that migrants cost jobs rather than acknowledging the vast body of evidence that shows that migration broadly speaking provides a net economic and employment benefit to Australia. Indeed, One Nation has said that once unemployment is fixed it is okay to increase immigration again, once again reinforcing this false link and showing that the issue of an environmentally sustainable population policy is just a cloak for the discrimination that hides behind their approach. It is a very marked difference from the approach of the Democrats, environment groups and the other organisations that I have mentioned.

The fact remains that many Australians have called for a population policy and, until such a thing is established, a smaller immigration intake until we work out the best overall population level of Australia in the long term.

talk.start.para: —Are you recommending anything?

—Despite many calls from many committees and inquiries for the establishment of a population policy, which is something that I would recommend, both the coalition and the ALP have refused to go very far down the track of developing such a policy. By contrast, the Democrats have had a population policy for many years. It is a pity that this has not been taken up by other parties, because perhaps there would have been less space available for parties such as One Nation to exploit in the misleading way that they currently are.

speech.para: Whether or not Pauline Hanson and the One Nation Party disappear, the concerns and questions will remain—whether we are talking about a population policy or whether we are talking about reversing the loss of control over our own economy to transnational corporations and to international money markets. The Democrats put forward what we believe to be valid and workable and positive solutions and contribute those to the public debate. We may not get it precisely right all the time; indeed, I have reservations about the workability and the appropriateness of a zero net migration policy. Even though that is the Democrats official policy, it is one that I am not fully comfortable with because I am not convinced that it is workable. That is something that I have not made any secret of within the party and I do not have any problem with stating that publicly.

I am nonetheless happy to pronounce it as Democrat policy because it does aim to address a legitimate concern in a positive way, and I am happy to be up-front, definitive, conclusive and specific about what the Democrats' policy is. It is much more definitive, I would suggest, than those of some other parties, in particular the ALP. I note Mr Gareth Evans's repeated hedging on this very issue of population policy and migration numbers on Meet the Press last week.

It is important, when we talk about immigration policy and we talk about multiculturalism, that we do not get hung up simply on numbers because it is not about numbers at the end of the day, it is about people. If migration stopped tomorrow, Australia would still be a multicultural society and it would still be crucial that we defended and supported the cohesive and dynamic nature of that multicultural society and the economic as well as social benefits that it brings. If our migration program is 100 people a year or 100,000 people a year, the vital, fundamental principle of treating all of those people equally and ensuring that all of them have the same rights as all other Australian citizens has still to be emphasised.

Ensuring adequate access to legal aid and ensuring that people have the same legal and human rights as everyone else whether they are newly arrived or whether they are fifth generation are things the Democrats believe need strong and constant reinforcement and support. One of the issues where unfortunately this is not demonstrated is in the current situation that applies in Australia. It is One Nation policy, but it was also the policy of the existing government, of requiring virtually all migrants to wait two years before they can access social security payments—income assistance—if they are in need.

I briefly refer to the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, very ably chaired by Senator Abetz, which looked into this issue of special benefit provisions relating to the newly arrived residents' waiting period. The report has been provided to the Senate and, unfortunately, there has not been an opportunity to speak to it to date. If and when that opportunity does arise, I will speak to it further, but I would like to emphasise that that issue is a perfect example of where we are sending a message out to people who are coming to Australia that they have fewer rights than existing Australians, that they are not able to access income support in times of need in the same way that other Australians can. This report, including the majority report of the government, actually illustrates that. It points to many situations where people are disadvantaged, where people are potentially being exploited and are not able to get redress.

Whilst I do not support the recommendation of the majority report for the current situation to continue, I commend it for actually acknowledging and pointing out the many disadvantages that people face. Certainly the Democrats believe that the two-year waiting period, particularly in relation to the special benefit, should be removed. People who are in absolute need should be able to access income support if they are here as legitimate members of the Australian community and have gone through all the hurdles and hoops to become Australian residents. We should extend that hand of assistance. As Senator Cooney said in his comments, this existing law implies that migrants are mendicants by nature. Where a genuine Australian resident is suffering genuine hardship, good principle suggests they should be given help. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to express my complete and unqualified support for the platform and philosophies of the Liberal Party of Australia. Tonight, I am also calling publicly for all Liberal supporters to stay involved in the Victorian division of the Liberal Party of Australia and to continue to work tirelessly for the re-election of the coalition government.

speech.para: Most senators would be aware that on Friday I was relegated from the third to the fourth spot of the coalition Senate ticket for the coming election. In the ALP, such a decision would be accompanied by bitterness, recriminations and factional brawling. Such brawling would spill over into future preselections and hurt the ALP electorally. I love my party. I do not want this to happen to it.

Those of you who have experienced an unexpected defeat in a preselection will know how personally hurtful it can be. At first, you are a little shocked, numbed to the reality. You search for the reason. All too often, you find that people you trusted let you down; that you misjudged people you had given loyalty; sometimes you find that the rules may not have been followed.

I would like to place on record my appreciation to those party members who supported me on the night and to the even greater number who have rung me since to express their disappointment: you have cheered me immensely. Thank you. Your kindness has made a difficult period in my life a lot easier.

To those party members who have threatened to resign, I say: stay involved. The Liberal Party needs people of principle to work in the organisational wing to ensure democracy. A vibrant political party encourages debate and channels disagreements constructively into improving policy. Please stay. Work for positive change. Do not be discouraged.

To the young professional women of the Liberal Party who feel betrayed that I was moved down the ticket, I say: do not allow this aberration to cause you to lose faith. The Liberal philosophy of equality of opportunity without quotas is vastly superior to the others. I will fight with you to ensure our party organisation acts on our principles. To the people of Victoria, whom I am honoured to represent, let me assure you that I will continue to represent you to the best of my ability. I have a year of my term still to go and I welcome your input and inquiries.

To the Premier of Victoria, whose government I praised in my maiden speech, I say: we do not have the luxury of a majority in the Senate; restrain your impatience and work to build a cooperative relationship with your federal colleagues. We are Victoria's repre sentatives in Canberra, not Canberra's representatives in Victoria. We are all on the same side.

Finally, at the risk of giving my valedictory a little earlier than usual, I would like to use this opportunity to thank my supporters. To the rank and file party members, mainly from federal electorate, I express my admiration for your fortitude and your persistence. I am sorry we did not quite make it.

To my staff—Di, Catherine, Sandra, Leanne and Conor—you have been great, and I look forward to seeing your careers blossom. I have already had a few ministers ask whether it is too soon to offer my excellent staff a job. I have told them it is.

To my political mentors and close friends Michael Kroger and Peter Costello and their staff, especially Anthony Smith: thanks, guys. We have been a team for 20 years. Your loyalty and your support is legendary. I am sorry I could not pull it off for you. And, of course, to my best friend and husband, Giuseppe: I love you more than anyone else. I hope to see more of you soon.

talk.start.para: —I wanted to put on the public record tonight a parliamentary appeal that was coordinated by Parliamentarians for Global Action. It is an appeal on defusing nuclear threats in South Asia. A number of members of this chamber signed the appeal and therefore I would like to read it into the Hansard :

speech.para: We, the members of Parliamentarians for Global Action, a network of 1,300 parliamentarians from 99 legislatures around the world,
Having
Applauded the signing of the landmark Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) by 149 countries on September 24, 1996, banning nuclear explosions for which PGA had worked for two decades,
Demanded that the test ban be just the first of many resolute steps towards a nuclear weapons-free world,
Welcomed therefore the recommendations put forward by the Canberra Commission to achieve a nuclear free world,
Congratulated the major bilateral nuclear disarmament agreements reached between Russia and the United States including the START I and II,
Strongly Condemned the under-water nuclear testing by France in the South Pacific in September 1995;
- Are Now
Extremely Dismayed by the testing of three nuclear devices by India on 11 May 1998 and the two subsequent testings on 13 May 1998 including a thermonuclear device,
Further Dismayed by Pakistan's response to India's testing of nuclear devices by conducting its own test of five nuclear devices on 28 May 1998,

Strongly Condemn the testing of these nuclear devices as it severely diminishes confidence and security in the South Asia region and beyond as well as undermines the spirit of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty,
Distressed that this will start a new and dangerous nuclear arms race in the region and beyond,

Extraordinarily Dismayed that India, and then Pakistan, tested nuclear weapons in the name of an outmoded conception of national security and Reiterate that the concept of security must include human security beyond a narrow military definition,
Alarmed that the effects of the escalation of nuclear armament in the Indian Subcontinent will have an environmental impact far beyond this region,
Drawing Upon our authority as elected representatives of citizens around the world;
A.
1. Call upon India and Pakistan to immediately and unconditionally sign the CTBT and disavow the deployment of nuclear weapons;
2. Call upon
. our governments and multilateral agencies to suspend loan/assistance programs to India and Pakistan; and
. our constituencies to send a clear message to States that test nuclear devices through a boycott of the products and commodities produced by these States
until India and Pakistan sign the CTBT and disavow the deployment of nuclear weapons;
3. Demand environmental impact assessments by an international body be carried out in the test sites and their surroundings;
B.
4. Urge India and Pakistan to come to the negotiation table in good faith to reach solutions to all outstanding problems between the two countries;
5. Strongly Appeal to the International Community to support India and Pakistan's negotiations by:
. creating incentives for peaceful policies;
. offering non-nuclear avenues for assuring their national security; and
. creating a Nuclear-Free Zone in the region.
6. Offer our network of legislators and international powers to facilitate such dialogue for peace-making in South Asia.
C.
7. Strongly Appeal
. to the United States Senate to immediately ratify the CTBT to set an example, as a leading Superpower, by paving the way for reducing the dangers of nuclear peril;
. to Russia and China to ratify the CTBT without delay;
I seek leave to table this statement.
Leave granted.
